Lawrence's ''Rainbow,'' opening in New York on Friday at the Paris.

LEAD: WHEN the Greeks left a wooden horse at the gates of Troy, the idea was to make a structure filled with people appear to be empty and lifeless. The suburban homeowner about to leave on vacation has quite the opposite task. He must make an empty and lifeless structure appear to be filled with people during his absence.
LEAD: LENYA A Life. By Donald Spoto. Illustrated. 371 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Ina Aronow did one wonderful job in reporting [ ''Cable TV Renews Interest in Local Government,'' April 9 ] on the renewed interest local community-access cable television channels are generating among Westchester's citizenry, with one notable omission - Rye City's RCTV/Rye Community Television - and one important correction.

LEAD: ''The Road Less Traveled,'' by M. Scott Peck, a Connecticut psychiatrist, was published by Touchstone, the trade paperback imprint of Simon & Schuster. An inspirational work with a strong nondenominational Christian tone, it presented teachings on discipline, love, grace and growth, supported by examples drawn from the author's psychiatric practice.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For Joe Dumars, who sat in the Detroit Pistons' locker room Friday night surrounded by cameras, microphones, and tape recorders, news media attention has been a long time coming. He spent the first three seasons of his professional career overshadowed by teammates like Isiah Thomas, Adrian Dantley and Bill Laimbeer.
LEAD: Students who enroll in Psychology 574 at the University of Kansas are soon hunting murderers and dancing at a supernatural disco as part of their homework.

LEAD: DOCUMENTING AMERICA, 1935-1943. Edited by Carl Fleischhauer and Beverly W. Brannan. (University of California, Paper, $24.95; Cloth, $60.) Photography as a reliable means of historical documentation has always been problematic. Even in the 1930's, when documentary photography came into its own, questions arose concerning objectivity and the use of photography as propaganda.

LEAD: Running the International Olympic Committee can be a headache, which may explain why Juan Antonio Samaranch, the 68-year-old I.O.C. president, wound up in a hospital in Barcelona, Spain, last week after conducting four days of meetings preparing for the 1992 Summer Games.

LEAD: In this far east reach of the Soviet Union where the Siberian hinterland abuts northern China, another of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ubiquitous peace initiatives - healing decades of border aggravation - is quietly proceeding apace.

LEAD: To the Editor: While Susan Heller Anderson's Hong Kong pearl piece (Travel, March 26) was a model of how to shop for jewelry, it obscured some points. It is nearly impossible to compare strands of pearls, or other pieces of jewelry, if they are not being evaluated side by side. Her comparison of Falconer's ''pink-hued pearls'' in Hong Kong and New York assumes there is only one shade of pink, and then overlooks the quality of the ''skin'' of the pearls.
LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded at least 18 Palestinians in the occupied Gaza Strip today, and a wounded 14-year-old boy died in the West Bank, Arab reports said.

LEAD: A newborn girl was found dead yesterday at 10:45 A.M. in an incinerator in the basement of the Franklin Plaza cooperative apartment building at 324 East 108th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

LEAD: Last month, a NATO military exercise came to an abrupt end when the West German and Turkish participants objected to an American proposal for the hypothetical use of battlefield nuclear weapons against an enemy on German and Turkish territory.

LEAD: This week's schedule of new Treasury issues is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills totaling $14 billion, followed by a $9 billion auction on Thursday of a new one-year bill.

Her partners in the endeavor were Kenneth Cooper, harpsichordist; Martha Caplin and Carol Zeavin, violinists; Linda Moss, violist; Annabelle Hoffman, cellist, and Sara

LEAD: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company said that William M. McCormick would resign as chairman, president and chief executive by the end of the year. Jack Byrne, chairman of the Fireman's Fund Corporation, the holding company, will assume Mr. McCormick's duties in an acting capacity.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: First place used to be so common that it was part of the Yankees' name, as in ''the first-place Yankees.'' Not long ago, superstar was attached to Jesse Barfield's name, as in Jesse Barfield, superstar.
LEAD: Galavision, a Spanish-language cable network, is eroding the lead of the two largest Spanish-language broadcasting networks in the United States.

LEAD: With solemn-faced actors reprising the first inauguration and a two-hour parade filling the narrow streets of lower Manhattan, New York City celebrated 200 years of Presidential government yesterday.

LEAD: Did Rick Pitino really dream that Trent Tucker would beat the Philadelphia 76ers with a 3-point shot? Or did he tell Tucker of the dream before the game as a motivational ploy to pull the leader of the team's ''Bomb Squad'' out of a slump?

LEAD: WHEN the latest upward explosion in stock prices began, the portfolio managers who run mutual funds were much more bullish than the investors in the funds. But the investors seem to have gotten the bullish religion in April, fund managers say.

LEAD: The Schomburg Plaza apartments rise tan and tall at the northern tip of Central Park, perched between affluence and poverty, between crack houses to the north and million-dollar cooperatives to the south on Fifth Avenue, between the extremes that so often define life in New York City.

LEAD: The Media Business WPP Group has begun an assault on another U.S. ad agency, making an unsolicited $730 million offer to buy the Ogilvy Group. If the bid succeeds, it will create the world's second-largest advertising company, after Saatchi & Saatchi, which like WPP is based in London. A merger would join some of the best-known names in advertising and continue the wave of mergers that has transformed the ad and marketing-communications industries.

LEAD: Frustrated after a judge dismissed charges against 86 anti-abortion demonstrators whose police identifications he questioned, the Buffalo police used new methods in arresting more than 40 protesters over the weekend. Each suspect was tagged by number and photographed with the arresting officer.

LEAD: Sergio Leone, the Italian director who revived western films in the 1960's and added distinction and style to a genre known as spaghetti westerns, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Rome. He was 67 years old.
LEAD: Walter Malley, deputy managing editor of The Buffalo News, was killed yesterday morning in an automobile accident in West Seneca, N.Y. He was 49 years old and lived in Elma, N.Y.

LEAD: Facing intense competition from Visa and Mastercard, as well as from its own products, American Express switched its $25 million gold card account on Friday from McCann-Erickson to Chiat/Day, New York, and its unit, Perkins/Butler Direct Marketing.
LEAD: Jim Wright is more than just the Speaker of the House, more than the nation's top ranking Democrat, second in line for the Presidency.

LEAD: Ron Harper outscored Michael Jordan, 31-30, and Larry Nance scored 8 points during a 13-6 third-quarter flurry as the Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Chicago Bulls, 96-88, today to even their playoff series at one game each.
LEAD: A list of Queens community school board candidates on Tuesday misidentified a candidate in District 30.
LEAD: Economic data to be released in the next few weeks will be critical in determining the course of interest rates, credit market participants and analysts say.

LEAD: During the winter before last season, the Yankees refused to trade Al Leiter. He was, they said, one of four young players who were untouchable. If Elliot Ness had been so untouchable, Robert Stack and Kevin Costner would have never made a television series and a movie about him.

LEAD: The clink of champagne glasses and the thwack of wooden mallets on plastic croquet balls are hardly sounds common to rural Georgia, but they mingled here today. The game favored by the landed gentry of 19th-century England, which has its own blue-blood pedigree in the United States, has found a home in this community halfway between Atlanta and

LEAD: This morning, on the occasion of the bicentennial of the first President's first inauguration, about 100 First Descendants got together for breakfast at Fraunces Tavern on Broad and Pearl Streets, to discuss who was related to whom.

LEAD: Av Westin, the former executive producer of the prime-time ABC News program ''20/20,'' has announced plans to leave the network to form his own production company, probably with the backing of either the Walt Disney Company or Warner Communications. Mr. Westin has been producer of the ABC ''Burning Questions'' documentaries since 1987, when he was removed from ''20/20'' after a dispute with Roone Arledge, the president of the news division.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera completed its first one-week ''Ring'' cycle in half a century to the sound of roof-ringing cheers Saturday night; it was one of those standing ovations that sweeps across the house like a wave. Now Wagnerians have had the chance they need to experience the great cycle, the new production and James Levine's musical interpretation within the time span for which

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's revival of its 1960 ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' production this season revolves around the considerable virtues of Luciano Pavarotti's Nemorino and Kathleen Battle's Adina. But at the Saturday matinee, there were newcomers to two of the secondary roles in this light-spirited Donizetti opera.

LEAD: Ellen A. Rowe, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Rowe of Dearborn, Mich., was married yesterday to Lewis W. Siegel, a son of Edith D. Siegel of New York and the late Marcus S. Siegel. Rabbi Michael Greenwald officiated at the Tavern on the Green in New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The United States earned its first points in its quest to qualify for the World Cup finals for the first time in 40 years with a 1-0 victory today over Costa Rica.

LEAD: A long-simmering labor dispute erupted yesterday when dozens of workers at the Tavern on the Green restaurant in Central Park walked off the job. Warner LeRoy, who operates the restaurant, issued a statement acknowledging that some workers had walked out. ''We are hiring a new staff and we will be open for business as usual on Monday,'' he said.
LEAD: The state water-pollution permits that New York City needs to operate its 14 sewage treatment plants were issued in violation of the law, according to a ruling issued last week.

LEAD: Students and workers fought the riot police with firebombs and rocks in downtown Seoul today after troopers blocked a rally called by labor and dissident groups to mark May Day. More than 2,900 people were arrested.

LEAD: The black chemical workers union has sued to stop the sale of the Mobil Corporation's assets in South Africa until the company negotiates a procedure for withdrawing from the country, the union said Saturday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The full-page advertisements placed in four New York newspapers today by Donald J. Trump calling for reinstatement of the death penalty grew out of the real-estate developer's ''deep-seated feeling that what's happening in society today has to be stopped,'' Mr. Trump said in a telephone interview Saturday.

LEAD: Nolan Ryan won the first battle between the best fastball pitchers in Texas today, leading the Texas Rangers past Roger Clemens and the Boston Red Sox, 2-1, on Rafael Palmeiro's two-run homer in the eighth inning.
LEAD: A 19-year-old woman was found strangled in Fort Tryon Park in the Inwood section of Manhattan on Saturday morning, the police said.

LEAD: Three weeks after he failed to win the Masters because he missed a 2-foot putt on the first playoff hole, Scott Hoch won the $1.25 million Las Vegas Invitational today by rolling in an 8-foot birdie putt on the fifth hole of a sudden-death playoff with Robert Wrenn.

LEAD: At Temple Beth Shalom in Roslyn, L.I., Dr. Deborah Miriam Yourish and Andrew Jay Porges, both graduates of the Cornell University Medical College and doctors at New York Hospital, were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Yourish of Lido Beach, L.I.

LEAD: Twenty years ago, Rod (the Rocket) Laver became the only tennis player to win the Grand Slam twice. The left-hander, who first accomplished this amazing feat in 1962, repeated it in 1969 by using a variety of strokes - cross-court volleys, pinpoint lobs and soft drop shots -rarely seen in this day of the blistering forehands and two-handed backhands.

LEAD: Dancing on a brand-new resilient stage floor just completed for its new season, the New York City Ballet served up an all-Balanchine feast on Saturday that was studded with fine debuts and excellence all around.

LEAD: Oil, which recently brought disaster to southeastern Alaska, has brought something very different to the native peoples here, 850 miles to the north: comfort, convenience and the seeds of destruction of their way of life.

LEAD: Ken Wregget heard the rumors back in March, and as a result the speculation began to circulate in his mind, too. As the Maple Leafs shopped to see what they could get for him, Wregget wrestled with what a trade might mean for him. He wasn't unhappy in Toronto, but he also thought he might be better off elsewhere.
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the National Magazine Awards misidentified the author honored in the reporting category. She is Robin Wright, not Robin White.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany forcefully reaffirmed their differing positions on NATO arms control strategy today and both declared that they were looking to the alliance summit meeting to restore a common front.
LEAD: Federal regulators have taken over four more insolvent savings and loan associations in three states, bringing the total under Government control to 220 in 32 states.

LEAD: A range of black and Hispanic officials and community groups in New York City say they are not persuaded that proposals for a two-house city legislature would adequately increase opportunities for minorities to win seats or power in a reconstituted city government.

LEAD: When Sullivan County officials realized last fall that the growing cost of government was about to send property taxes soaring, they began looking for a less painful solution. They found thousands: the out-of-towners who come to the Catskills' resort hotels.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the billionaire developer, formally made his long-expected move into Nevada gaming last week by filing incorporation papers for Trump Nevada Inc. Mike Rumbolz, former chairman of the Nevada Gaming Control Board, will serve as president of the Las Vegas-based company that will hold the Trump Nevada casinos.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 London and Bonn agreed to differ on NATO disarmament strategy and declared that they were looking to the alliance meeting at the end of May to restore a common front. Page A1
LEAD: A drug-testing program for high school athletes in Woodstock, Vt. -the first such program in the state and, possibly, the nation - has been started despite controversy over its implementation.

LEAD: Leslie H. Lynn, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Horwitz of New York, and J. Andrew Rahl Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Rahl of Evanston, Ill., were married yesterday at the restaurant Bouley in Manhattan. Judge Bruce Kaplan of Family Court officiated.
LEAD: Float tubes offer fishermen a way to move quietly across the water in search of their catch. But, like inner tubes, they can tip over.
LEAD: Some things simply do not figure. David Cone does not struggle in the third inning; the Mets do not normally succumb to Dave Smith in the ninth. But today at the Astrodome, both happened.

LEAD: Ralph E. Adams, a World War II submariner who helped rescue a downed flier who is now President of the United States, died of cancer at his home on April 21. He was 76 years old. Mr. Adams, a career Navy sailor, was was part of a rescue party sent from the submarine Finback on Sept. 4, 1944, to pick up Lieut.

LEAD: At bus stops and subway stations in inner cities around the country, a well-dressed black trumpeter grins from a Benson & Hedges billboard and says his brand of cigarettes is ''for people who like to smoke.''

LEAD: Miles of radishes, great stands of celery and fields of sweet corn, carrots and lettuce thrive in southern Florida's fertile mucklands, a powerful testament to the union of engineering, biology and chemistry that has fed America for two generations.

LEAD: Lionvision is the name of a new satellite television network soon to be offered to fans of Penn State sports at a cost of almost $1,300. Early responses indicate that the break-even point of 2,500 subscribers will be met easily.

LEAD: The WPP Group P.L.C., the British holding company that two years ago executed a hostile takeover of J. Walter Thompson, has opened an assault on another venerable American advertising company, the Ogilvy Group.

LEAD: Isiah Thomas has a broken bone in his left hand that throbs every time someone hits it. He has played cautiously for three weeks, picking his spots to score while letting teammates carry the load offensively.

LEAD: At the Hotel Pierre in New York, Mindy Lois Schneider and Dr. Michael Scott Lesser were married yesterday by Rabbis Irving Greenberg and Joseph Singer. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schneider of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Lesser is the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Lesser of Boca Raton,
LEAD: Fierce competition for readers and scoops is transforming the high end of the Sunday newspaper scene in Britain.

LEAD: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, has presented a plan for Israeli-supervised elections in the occupied territories. The elections would produce Palestinian representatives who would negotiate with Israel on interim autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza Strip. He did not address what, if anything, might follow the interim arrangement.

LEAD: The savings and loan rescue taking shape in Congress improves on President Bush's original plan by making the owners and stockholders of savings and loan associations risk more of their own money and less of the public's. But the House Banking Committee now threatens to weaken the plan with exemptions and a tacked-on subsidy scheme for low-cost housing.

LEAD: This is the coldest, nastiest place in America to do business, a place where it can snow on the Fourth of July and where even now the only sign of spring is that snow by the roads is beginning to turn brown from dust.

LEAD: If Salvador Garcia of Mexico had not fallen at the start of the Boston Marathon two weeks ago, he would have probably finished the race and have been too exhausted to run today in the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon.

LEAD: Amid accusations of misdeeds and mismanagement on some New York City community school boards, city voters and parents of children in the public-school system will vote tomorrow for members of the 32 decentralized community school boards. At stake are 288 seats, 9 on each local board. The elections are the eighth since the system was decentralized in 1970 to provide community control of local schools.

LEAD: Should public officials, political leaders and employees of New York City's Board of Education be prohibited from serving on community school boards? Just days before tomorrow's election of 288 local school board members, U.S. District Judge Mark Costantino said no.

LEAD: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. announced that it was withdrawing as a primary dealer in Treasury securities, effective immediately. The London-based bank said that while it had not lost money in its Treasury operation, ''our return on capital invested has not been commensurate with what the bank obtains in other businesses.

LEAD: At the end of an outdoor beatification ceremony here today, two dozen barefoot boys and girls danced before Pope John Paul II while a congregation of hundreds of thousands sang a lilting hymn in the Malagasy language.
LEAD: A RUNNER who was raped at gunpoint in Central Park at dusk one March day six years ago remembers how invincible, invulnerable and completely in control of her life being fit had made her feel.

LEAD: BOOK fairs abroad have become increasingly important to American publishers, which are growing more international in ownership and in their publishing vision. This year American publishers can choose among at least 15 of the fairs, from Spain to Singapore and from Brussels to Belgrade.

LEAD: The Control Data Corporation's hasty withdrawal from the supercomputer business has sharpened the debate over whether new Japanese competition to build and sell the powerful computers is threatening the dominance of the United States in the field.

LEAD: America's space program began and blossomed in competition with the Soviet Union. But with the rivalry easing, it's possible to think what was unthinkable during the chilly cold war years: Let the superpowers give up costly competitive extravaganzas and go into space together.

LEAD: Senator William J. Gormley of Atlantic County, a moderate in a field dominated by conservatives, is hoping lessons from past campaigns and instincts born of a lifelong immersion in politics will enable him to pull an upset in the June 7 Republican primary for governor.
LEAD: Like a plant seeking sunlight, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia has strained toward the glow of the news media for many years. Now he is basking in it.

LEAD: When the Control Data Corporation, one of two manufacturers of supercomputers in the United States, abruptly dropped out of the race to build the fastest machines in the world, the Japanese were both startled and a bit apprehensive.

LEAD: Fred J. Meyer, the chief financial officer of the Omnicom Group, has denied that the giant marketing-communications company is acquiring shares in the Boase, Massimi & Pollitt Partnership, the British advertising agency fighting a hostile takeover bid by a French agency.

LEAD: AT the crest of the blacktop road that winds amid the woodlands of his Long Island estate, past the stone pillars and around the circular driveway, through the front door of the brick mansion and down the hall in the wood-paneled library, Ogden Phipps is looking at a notebook.

LEAD: Hubbell vs. Spahn Q. Did Warren Spahn ever win a game against Carl Hubbell? A. By the time Spahn started winning games in the National League, and he won 363 of them, Hubbell was starting his second year of retirement after notching 253 victories, all in the National League. The two Hall of Fame left-handers had one season in common, 1942, when Hubbell's career was in its twilight and Spahn's was dawning.

LEAD: Engineers decided today to replace an apparently defective fuel pump in the shuttle Atlantis in an operation that space officials said would set back the launching for the shuttle's mission until at least Friday or Saturday.

LEAD: A new yacht-racing series in New York Harbor is drawing competitors who are among the top female sailors in the United States.
LEAD: TO many, fly fishing is an art learned over a lifetime.

Dr. Barbara Duffy Spencer, of the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island, officiated at the Mill River Club in Brookville, L.I.

LEAD: FEMALE runners who reach their 40's can look forward to continued improvements in performance, better health and the confidence to cope with the stresses of mid-life more than nonexercisers, according to Priscilla Welch, who won the New York City Marathon at age 42 in 1987.

LEAD: With lawmakers pressing to finish this year's legislative business in eight weeks, as opposed to last year's 11-month marathon, the New York Legislature returns here Monday for the second half of a session that is expected to be dominated by issues of crime and justice and a lack of money.

LEAD: Cracking the Japan Scandal The dark-suited, unsmiling men of the Tokuso, the Tokyo special prosecutors' office, last week helped topple the Government. They gained praise, and some criticism, for their handling of a corruption scandal. Page A8. Revising the '92 Script The battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1992 will be dramatically different from the last two campaigns if Jesse Jackson decides to run for Mayor of Washington.

LEAD: It is rare that a bit of iffy political news coming three years before a Presidential election sends such a large jolt through the system. But when the news involves the Rev. Jesse Jackson, some electricity is inevitable.

LEAD: Dennis Rivera, executive vice president of the long-troubled Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, was elected president of the union on Saturday, winning 90 percent of the 22,000 ballots cast.

LEAD: Edward Villella, one of the great American ballet stars, owes his career in dance to a baseball accident. In 1946, when he was 10 years old, Mr. Villella was knocked unconscious in a sandlot ball game in Bayside, Queens, where he grew up. His mother wanted to keep him off the streets as a result, so when she enrolled her daughter in the School of American Ballet, she mentioned that she had a son at home.

LEAD: At the bare minimum, dramatic works about the Holocaust have an obligation to restore vivid immediacy to horrors that scoundrels and the passing of time would have the world forget. As presented in good conscience but with scant competence by the Circle in the Square, Joshua Sobol's ''Ghetto'' is too lifeless to meet this minimal requirement.

LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about steaks described the grading of Certified Angus beef incorrectly. The beef is graded by the Government as either choice or prime and also conforms to specifications set by the American Angus Association, a private beef cattle registry.

LEAD: A Canadian chamber ensemble, the Tudor Singers of Montreal, is to join the Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. in a benefit, ''In Concert Against AIDS.'' Funds raised will go to a group residence for AIDS patients, Bailey House of the AIDS Resource Center. Tickets are $25 to $200.

LEAD: Three crewmen on a United States Navy submarine were swept overboard by a wave today as the vessel, the Barbel, was on surface patrol off a Japanese island. One man was rescued and two were missing, American officials said. In Washington, a Defense Department spokesman said he had heard reports of the missing men but had no details.

LEAD: Coleman A. Young, the Mayor of this troubled city and one of the country's first black mayors, appears headed for more difficulty than usual if he runs for a fifth term in November, as most Detroiters expect him to do.

LEAD: Responding to increasing violence in the occupied territories between Palestinians and Jewish settlers, two Israeli Cabinet ministers demanded today that the settlers be allowed to shoot more freely in clashes with Arabs.

LEAD: The construction of a new wing at this city's most popular museum, the Museum of Anthropology, and an exhibition opening soon at its leading art museum highlight what is becoming a much-debated question throughout Canada: How are exhibiting institutions to treat both old and new works by American Indians?

LEAD: Lisa Pam Yarvis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin R. Rabbi Morris Feldman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

LEAD: A declarer in a suit contract must be sensitive to the possibilities of promotion, and South on the diagramed deal had a special reason for having this subject on his mind. LEAD: AFTER more than a decade of bitter legal wrangling, the moment when it counts is at hand in the huge patent fight between the Eastman Kodak Company and the Polaroid Corporation.

LEAD: Lois Margaret Brenner and Robert Stein were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York. Jacqueline Silbermann, Administrative Judge of the Civil Court of the City of New York, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: When thousands of cheering and banner-waving Qinghua University students left campus last week to join an enormous demonstration that crumpled police lines and forced the Government to agree to a discussion, they forgot one thing: their leaders.

LEAD: After months of debate, the partners in the Austrian Government's coalition have formally agreed to apply for membership in the European Community, but it is an open question whether the community nations want Austria.

LEAD: The skyscrapers housing Japan's most powerful Government offices lie in a central Tokyo district called Kasumigaseki, which means the gate enshrouded by fog.

LEAD: Nobody is telling the truth. In weeks of arguments and pronouncements about West Germany, NATO, the Soviet Union and short-range nuclear weapons, no diplomat, politician or national leader has had the courage to say plainly what lies beneath it all. LEAD: The average Japanese worker's monthly wage climbed 3.6 percent after inflation in the last fiscal year, the highest real growth rate in 14 years, the Labor Ministry said today. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Gov. Buddy Roemer said today that budget reductions forced by rejection of a tax overhaul package will ''go beyond common sense,'' adding that he is studying closing some universities and hospitals.

LEAD: The Walt Disney Company opened its $400 million Disney-MGM Studios theme park today. LEAD: When a young team wins two significant events within a short period it is reasonable to conclude that the players are on their way to the top. Judith Fields, Mamdouh Guenena, John Scheuermann and Mark Lake, all of Manhattan, captured the Flight B Regional Swiss Teams in Hofstra, L.I., on April 2. Five weeks earlier, with Mark Stratton playing instead of Lake, they had won the Flight B Grand National Team title and qualified for playoffs in Chicago in July.

LEAD: Sir John Boyd, a miner's son who fought off leftists to lead the powerful British union of engineering workers, died Sunday at his home in Eastbourne, south of London, the BBC said today. He was 71.
LEAD: The Government can require Atlantic and Gulf Coast shrimpers to equip their nets with a device intended to save sea turtles in danger of extinction, a Federal judge ruled today.
LEAD: A Federal judge struck down the death penalty law in Illinois today, raising doubts about the fate of 121 prisoners on the state's death row.

LEAD: TENNIS Frenchwoman Gains: Christine Damas of France defeated Sabine Auer of West Germany, 6-0, 5-7, 7-5, yesterday in first-round play at the Virginia Slims tournament in Hamburg, West Germany. In other matches, Jo-Anne Faull of Australia beat Silke Frankl of West Germany, 6-3, 6-2; Nathalie Tauziat of France downed Petra Huber of Austria, 6-2, 6-2, and Silke Meier of West Germany defeated Steffi Menning, 6-2, 6-4.(AP)

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the dispute in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over short-range nuclear weapons described the replacement for the Lance missile incorrectly. The new missiles are to have increased range, but not increased explosive yield.

LEAD: The Eglevsky Ballet presented a program of oddities in Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University tonight. Not the least of these oddities was the rarely seen ''Carnival in Venice,'' also known as ''Satanella,'' choreographed by Marius Petipa to a grandiloquent score by Cesare Pugni.

LEAD: It took five years and $35 million to renovate the Central Park Zoo, and the city seems to have thought of just about everything to make the place comfortable for both beasts and people - except the possibility that a man might need to change a baby's diaper. LEAD: If the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X had met for an hour or so, what would they have found to say to each other? Jeff Stetson undertook to answer that question in a 1987 one-act play, an American Playhouse adaptation of which can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channels 13 and 49. Although neither the clash of principles nor the affinity of personalities portrayed here offers any surprises, the scenes in which the men reveal the shared pain behind their very different philosophies of the racial struggle are compelling.

He was traded to the Edmonton Oilers by the Rangers in 1986 and won a Stanley Cup with the Oilers in 1987 after joining them late in the season.

LEAD: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, said yesterday that the low turnout in the community school board elections Tuesday appeared to demonstrate that the current structure was unacceptable and needed substantial change.

LEAD: A military jet crashed during a training flight today, and the pilot died from injuries suffered when he ejected moments earlier, Marines Corps officials said. The single-seat AV-8 Harrier crashed about 9 A.M. near a training airfield at the Marine Corps Recruiting Depot near Beaufort. The pilot, whose name was withheld, was one of 25,600 marines and sailors taking part in the Solid Shield '89 training exercise, which began today and is scheduled to run until May 20.
LEAD: Three days after becoming the target of a takeover attempt, the Ogilvy Group reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 10.8 percent from the comparable period last year.

LEAD: Walter H. Blucher, an authority on city planning who was a former director of the American Society of Planning Officials, died of bone cancer April 20 at his home in Napa, Calif. He was 88 years old.
LEAD: The Koch administration is considering proposing a surcharge on the New York City income tax to help balance the budget for the coming fiscal year, a city official said yesterday.

Police officers said the attack Tuesday night was presumably the work of leftist guerrillas battling the American-backed Government. But the rebels, in a communique broadcast on their clandestine radio, denied that.

LEAD: Argentina put into practice today a series of tax, pricing and exchange policies intended to stabilize the economy and turned to the country's largest corporations for $500 million in loans.

LEAD: CHARTERED by an act of Congress in 1905, the American Academy in Rome is an interdisciplinary center for study of the fine arts and humanities. The Academy's 10-acre, 10-building compound includes Villa Aurelia, a 17th-century summer palace.

LEAD: The public interest lobby Common Cause said today that an independent prosecutor should be named to help the House ethics committee decide whether to investigate Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who pressed for the ethics inquiry of Speaker Jim Wright.

LEAD: Julie Andrews and Carol Burnett -who last appeared together at Carnegie Hall 27 years ago - will give a benefit performance for the hall on June 8 at 8 P.M. ABC-TV will tape the show for broadcast in the fall.
LEAD: For the second time in a week, ABC television has decided to pull a special hourlong program dramatizing real-life episodes from its prime-time schedule.

LEAD: Charlie Bailey, Memphis State University's head football coach, resigned yesterday amid a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into reports that two of his athletes lied about contacts with school boosters.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian leader, indicated today for the first time that he is prepared to return home as head of state in a government dominated by men installed by the Vietnamese Army in an invasion 10 years ago.
LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell a subsidiary, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, to an outside group for about $460 million.

LEAD: A Palestinian wielding a 10-inch knife and shouting ''God is great!'' went on a rampage along Jewish West Jerusalem's main shopping street today, killing two Israelis, including a 90-year-old man, and wounding three others, among them a 90-year-old woman.

LEAD: A new device that greatly eases breathing for patients dependent on oxygen therapy has proved so successful in clinical tests that it is now being studied for broader uses in the United States and abroad. The device, which is portable, allows oxygen-dependent patients to pursue normal activities like dining out, traveling and even playing golf.

LEAD: Frustrated because the State Legislature has refused to act on his attempts to recover unclaimed bottle deposits, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today threatened to appoint a special commission to investigate the bottling industry if the lawmakers did not take action.

LEAD: Employing a new state law intended to hold parents responsible for the criminal activity of their children, the police here have arrested the mother of a 17-year-old suspect in a rape case on the ground that she condoned his membership in a street gang.
LEAD: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee has recommended approval of a drug used to treat an AIDS-related condition that can lead to blindness.

LEAD: In its second important aircraft order within weeks, USAir Group Inc. announced a $1.3 billion deal today with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to buy 20 MD-82 aircraft and take options on 20 more.
LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today signed into law a bill allowing New York corporations to institute ''poison pill'' shareholder rights plans.
LEAD: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: In his most detailed response to the efforts of the New York City Charter Revision Commission, Mayor Edward I. Koch said he has ''some doubts'' about a proposal that would radically alter the shape of a government he has led for more than 11 years.
LEAD: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were mostly down in taxable funds but up in tax-exempt funds for the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: The Bush Administration intends to appoint Drew E. Altman, New Jersey's Commissioner of Human Services, to oversee the nation's $100 billion Medicare program, health care experts and officials of the Department of Health and Human Services said today.
LEAD: The Bush Administration said today that the performance of the nation's schools was ''merely average'' and ''stagnant,'' with no improvement despite increases in spending.
LEAD: A former Charlevoix City Attorney, Jeffery W. Van Treese, pleaded guilty Tuesday to possessing cocaine.

LEAD: The knack for putting together consistently imaginative concert programs is one that only a few conductors ever acquire. Erich Leinsdorf, as New York Philharmonic audiences have long known, is one of the few. It is a little odd: he has access to the same music libraries as everyone else. But his long experience, catholic sympathies and thoughtfully skewered view of the orchestral repertory combine to give many of his programs a fascinating look and, often enough, a satisfying sound as well.

LEAD: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, out of service for repairs, reported a water leak today inside the plant's drywell. Operators were filling reactor systems with water for testing when safety valves began leaking, said a statement by GPU Nuclear Corporation.

LEAD: Men on the Howard University campus are boxing themselves in - in terms of hairstyles, that is. One of the newest cuts - or more accurately, shapes -to catch the fancy of black men in particular resembles a box. The sides of the head are shaved close, and the top is squared off and leveled, leaving three to four inches of hair standing at well-clipped attention.

LEAD: Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Stephenie Florence Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Miller of Woodstown, N.J., to James Graham Reinhard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Reinhard of Greenville. The Rev. Adam M. Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony.

LEAD: IN the darkness before dawn, the port of Piraeus, Greece, near Athens, is already rumbling to life. Sleepyheaded backpackers are coughed from the bellies of large cargo and passenger ferries, as others wait in line to load. These ocean-going ferries carry supply trucks, the lifeline to outlying islands, as well as tourists and
LEAD: FOREIGNERS in growing numbers are among the potential buyers of resale homes these days - both suburban houses and urban apartments - as the world increasingly becomes a global village.

LEAD: Along with the latest examples of film technology, new cameras keep coming across my transom. Most are me-too models of the point-and-shoot variety, of interest only because they fill a marketing niche in their makers' product lines. But a few are curious enough to make me load them up instantly and head out the door.

LEAD: A hectic week for Wendy Lian Williams, a United States Olympic bronze medalist, ended with an upset victory over the Olympic gold medalist, Xu Yanmei, in the women's platform event today at the World Diving Cup.

LEAD: San Antonio's former Mayor regained her office by a commanding margin, and the Mayors of Dallas and Fort Worth held wide leads in early returns from Texas cities today. In El Paso, none of the six candidates appeared to have enough votes to avoid a runoff.

LEAD: The World Health Organization is planning to offer increased medical aid to Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied territories as part of an emerging compromise aimed at preventing the United States from withdrawing from the organization, diplomats say.
LEAD: Sander Simon, a former construction and manufacturing executive who also published books on sports figures, died Friday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: The Gothic revival style in 19th-century European furnishings was spurred in the late 1820's by the spread of nationalism and religious revivalism. What resulted was chairs, chests, clocks and tablewares embellished with Gothic spires, trefoils, crosses and knights in shining armor, images spiced by fantasy and enriched by glitter or the jewellike colors of medieval stained-glass windows.

LEAD: Tomorrow, when his staging of ''Swan Lake'' launches American Ballet Theater's eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House with a gala, Mikhail Baryshnikov will be imagining that somewhere in the audience is a budding romantic who must be placated. The 41-year-old artistic director of the company seems to have had his former, impatient self in mind when re-staging ''Swan Lake,'' having said his main goal was to direct the ballet toward such an emotional climax that few would dare leave the theater early.

LEAD: Aleksandr Mogilny, the Soviet hockey player who defected in Stockholm earlier this week to join the Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League, spent his first full day in the United States in seclusion today as club officials discussed his future with American immigration officials and the N.H.L.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Keating Sands of Oyster Bay, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Douglass Sands to Lawrence Talmage Petty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Petty of Chevy Chase, Md. The couple plan to marry in October.

LEAD: THE PORT OF MISSING MEN. By Mary-Ann Tirone Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) Reading this delightfully unexpected, offbeat little book is like taking a ride on the Crazy Mouse at the carnival: you never know what twists or turns it will take next. Mary-Ann Tirone Smith's third novel, ''The Port of Missing Men,'' is set in 1936; as it begins, our heroine, 15-year-old Lily Neelan, and her mother, Gertie, are on board the Normandie.

LEAD: Edward Abbey, who died in March at the age of 62, seemed, at his best, the nonpareil ''nature writer'' of recent decades. It was a term he came to detest, a term used to pigeonhole and marginalize some of the more intriguing American writers who are dealing with matters central to us - yet it can be a ticket to oblivion in the bookstores.

LEAD: JIM WRIGHT, says an old friend, has his jaw out and the bit in his teeth. That's Texas talk for he has not yet begun to fight. The one-time boxer is hunkering down for his final battle, a fight to convince the House ethics committee that he did not break the rules of Congressional conduct.

LEAD: GOING DUTCH Smile when you suggest ''Going Dutch'' at Hofstra University. The people there take the hint literally, and today, for the sixth year in a row, the Hempstead campus will celebrate its Dutch heritage with a Dutch Festival. The four-hour program begins at noon.
LEAD: Carl Thackery of England and Barbara Moore of New Zealand captured the men's and women's races of the 10-mile Trevira Twosome in Central Park yesterday, but they lost the overall competition.

The retailers unwittingly pass along the entire $100 overcharge to unsuspecting consumer purchasers. Who has the right to sue to collect damages from the manufacturers?

LEAD: The timing could hardly be better. Two hundred years ago, almost to the day, on May 5, 1789, Versailles witnessed the opening session of the Estates-General, soon to become the National Assembly. That day is usually viewed as marking the starting point of the French Revolution.

LEAD: ''American Bandstand'' notwithstanding, the measure of a commercial dance record is almost never its beat. The history of dance music is one of bad records with good beats and good records with monotonous thuds. The beat is at most an instigator, a means toward a greater reward.

LEAD: Taxes and fees are going up $1 billion in New York State. New Hampshire has frozen state hiring. Elizabeth, N.J., has laid off about 225 city workers. Here in Boston, officials expect hundreds of layoffs of teachers and municipal employees.
LEAD: DELAY, the tactic that Shoreham opponents used to drive the Long Island Lighting Company into a deal to kill the reactor, has a new champion: the United States Secretary of Energy.

LEAD: IN an effort to preserve public access to mile-long Moody Beach, the town of Wells is preparing to get two appraisals of the beachfront lots, one for buying easements for recreation and onefor buying the land outright. If the cost is too high, said Jonathan Carter, the Wells Town Manager, the town will ask the state to buy the beach through its program of buying public lands.
LEAD: A former Russian-language specialist for the Air Force has been arrested here on espionage charges, accused of trying to give American military secrets to the Soviet Union.

LEAD: CONFRONTATION with alien tongues sorts travelers into three groups. The adepts, at one extreme, ''have an ear.'' Landing in Madrid for breakfast, they're able to chat up the waiter by dinnertime. At the other extreme are the blithely monolingual, confident that pantomime, loud repetitions of their native speech and the kindness of strangers will carry any day.

LEAD: A rapidly expanding market for shark meat and shark fins has prompted the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council to call for emergency restrictions on harvesting the animals.
LEAD: Planners for the Whitbread Around-the-World Race added an American port to the itinerary this year. But there still may not be a United States team in the sailboat race.
LEAD: Does the National Football League have an ulterior motive in creating that new trans-Atlantic league, which is due to start operations next spring as the International Football League?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WHY ME? The Sammy Davis Jr. Story. By Sammy Davis Jr., Jane Boyar and Burt Boyar. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: Oliver L. North attacked Congress before a cheering crowd of supporters today, saying too many members interfere in foreign affairs, but he avoided any mention of his recent conviction on three felony charges.

LEAD: For his farewell appearance this afternoon as artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Charles Wadsworth had a range of choices. He could have stepped out of character and taken a solo piano turn with something valedictory such as Beethoven's ''Lebewohl'' Sonata. Many in the Alice Tully Hall audience for this final concert of the society's 20th season will be in the mood for something at least that sentimental.

LEAD: ''DID you know that Jane Fonda is 52 years old?'' my 13-year-old daughter asked. That was a loaded question if I ever heard one. ''Yes, I know that,'' I replied, and waited for the other shoe to fall. ''She looks really good,'' my daughter said. ''Yes, she does.'' I had my hand on the cookie jar as I answered her, but

Kunzelmann of Macon, Ga., and John P. Kunzelmann of Longwood, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O.
LEAD: IT took the jurors in the trial of Oliver L. North 12 days and a prayer to reach conclusions about the Iran-contra affair. History may need more help and certainly more time.
LEAD: WEST OF EDEN The End of Innocence at Apple Computer. By Frank Rose. 356 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Gerard Schwarz is to lead the Waterloo Festival Orchestra in Barber's Adagio for Strings, Copland's ''Symphonic Ode,'' the Liszt arrangement of Schubert's ''Wanderer Fantasie'' and Franck's Symphony in D minor on June 24, the opening weekend of the Waterloo Festival. The pianist Jorge Bolet is to be the soloist in the

LEAD: ''Being good in business is the most fascinating kind of art,'' Andy Warhol once said. That Mr. Warhol's pop art is both good business and fascinating was demonstrated last week when his portrait, ''Shot Red Marilyn,'' a 1964 depiction of Marilyn Monroe, was auctioned at Christie's in New York. The price, $4.07 million, was the highest ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist, who died in 1987.

LEAD: Moose and squirrel are back. In the summer of 1964, when we last left our heroes - that plucky little rodent with the aviator helmet and his tall, antlered friend with the dimwit voice - you'll remember that their cartoon show had been canceled by NBC. Rocky and Bullwinkle, along with those sinister spies, Boris (''Keel Moose'') Badenov and Natasha (''Boris, dollink'')
LEAD: ''FLING any stuffed cats lately?'' - Flemish villagers may well accost each other, in the Belgian city of Ieper.

LEAD: I the predawn hours of Feb. 18, 1987, a fire of unknown origin destroyed much of the complex equipment at New York Telephone's Bushwick Central Office. More than 40,000 customers - including hospitals and police - were out of service. Ordinarily, damages this extensive would take six months or more to repair.

LEAD: HAVING broken with Moscow as far back as the early 1970's, Italy's Communist leaders are savoring the fact that their criticism of Stalinism and their calls for democracy have been echoed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ''When we used to say these things, we were considered heretics,'' the party's new leader, Achille

LEAD: Colette de Marneffe, a daughter of Mrs. Anthony Ferranti of Arlington, Mass., and Dr. Francis de Marneffe of Cambridge, Mass., and Dublin, N.H., was married yesterday to Martin Paul Trimble, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. James A. Trimble of Philadelphia. The bridegroom's father, assisted by the Rev. John E.

LEAD: Adele Marguerite Raso and Herman Henri Raspe, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the Most Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Franklin Lakes, N.J., by the Rev. John C. Wagner.

LEAD: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, Jacqueline Marie Carr, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Carr of New York, was married yesterday to Richard B. Lonoff, a son of Violet Lonoff of Toms River, N.J., and Harold Lonoff of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church officiated.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Shirley Rich, the acknowledged doyenne of theatrical casting directors, claims there are even people in the entertainment industry who still don't understand what she does. ''They confuse us with agents,'' says Ms. Rich, whose career spans virtually the history of casting directors, from her first job as an assistant to Rodgers & Hammerstein to the present.
LEAD: ABSENT FRIENDS By Frederick Busch. 278 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: THERE is a new sound coming from the third world - the sound of superpowers pulling up stakes. From Afghanistan to Syria to Cambodia to Ethiopia to Angola to Nicaragua, both the United States and the Soviet Union are looking for the exits. And as they take their cold war home with them, both are coming to recognize the nasty, tribal and intractable nature of some regional conflicts that have consumed them for decades.
LEAD: On the essay March 19 that proposed leasing subtidal lands (''Tapping Income Buried in Public Land''), I offer the following comments to present a balanced view of this issue.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S housing crisis - rising homelessness, declining homeownership and skyrocketing rents - can be managed, but only with a renewed commitment from the Federal Government.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has looked down the road and does not like what it sees.

LEAD: The panel rewriting New York City's charter rejected a proposal yesterday to have the five borough presidents serve on an expanded City Council and decided instead to recommend new administrative roles for them.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To provide low-cost housing for people 62 years old and older, the Federal National Mortgage Association has made $100 million in new mortgage money available to lending institutions under four innovative programs. The pilot project will provide 1,400 low-cost mortgages throughout the country to see if the programs are viable options for people at or near retirement age.

LEAD: ONE OF MY FIRST LESSONS AT THE New York Restaurant School nearly six years ago was the easiest: If you boil heavy cream, it thickens into an instant sauce. Spike it with vermouth or applejack, whisk in a little Pommery mustard or a touch of thyme, and shallots or ginger, or both, and you've got everything covered from chicken and fish to pasta and veal.
LEAD: The fascinating aspect of the Golden State Warriors' success this season is that they have dared to be different.

LEAD: IT'S like the light at the end of the tunnel. Winter is over, and the sunshine, scents and colors of spring invite even the most serious-minded out to play. The experience is commonly known as spring fever, and people find it harder to work and carry out their assigned responsibilities.

LEAD: ''Before I came here . . . I thought swimming was me and my friends taking turns running through the open fire hydrant,'' says Jonathan, 9 years old, the guest of a Fresh Air Fund host family in Massachusetts. Jonathan was one of nearly 10,000 inner-city youngsters between the ages of 5 and 12 who spent a free vacation in the country last year.
LEAD: CONNECTICUT opponents of the Westchester County Airport last week praised a proposal by two Westchester legislators to ban noisy flights at night.
LEAD: THE sounds of sniffles emanating from the George Street Playhouse these matinees and evenings are those of an audience in the grip of a great, affecting play.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I can't imagine the Mets without Mookie. He's the heart and soul and humor of the team, and my favorite baseball player.

LEAD: IN a Congressional session thus far devoid of serious policy-making, it is probably fitting that the first showdown between Democrats and President Bush comes over the largely symbolic question of how much to raise the minimum wage.

LEAD: THE proposal recently defeated by the Suffolk County Legislature to freeze the wages of county employees deserves further examination: not because it was right, but because its motivation is so dangerously wrong.

LEAD: IN an effort to preserve public access to mile-long Moody Beach, the town of Wells is preparing to get two appraisals of the beachfront lots, one for buying easements for recreation and onefor buying the land outright. If the cost is too high, said Jonathan Carter, the Wells Town Manager, the town will ask the state to buy the beach through its program of buying public lands.
LEAD: 'Petrol Police' Patrol Border Of Singapore
LEAD: SUMMER OF '49 By David Halberstam. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $21.95.

LEAD: The champions turned out the other night. Florence Griffith Joyner, the Olympic gold medalist, and Jim Burt of the New York Giants were among those honored at the 17th annual Dinner of Champions of the National Multiple Sclerosis Foundation, which raised more than $2 million at the Marriott.
