LEAD: JOHN H. HASTINGS is talking in numbers. ''Fourteen and fifteen at full and five at seven,'' he says through headphones. ''Four and five at five and seven through nine out.''
LEAD: Just two weeks before final exams begin, students at this University of California campus had to cross picket lines to attend class during a two-day strike by graduate students last week.
LEAD: THE LATE-SUMMER PASSION OF A WOMAN OF MIND By Rebecca Goldstein. 261 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: TERRITORY OF LIES The Exclusive Story of Jonathan Jay Pollard: The American Who Spied on His Country for Israel and How He Was Betrayed. By Wolf Blitzer. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

LEAD: ON April 19, a 28-year-old woman was discovered in a Manhattan park, brutally raped and beaten into a coma. On April 29, a 19-year-old woman was found dead, strangled and probably raped, in another Manhattan park. The two women, both of whom moved to New York City to advance their careers, were nine years apart in age; the incidents were separated by only 10 days and 100 blocks.
LEAD: MY friend Pam returned from a trip to California. Instead of telling about California, Pam was much more excited about the flight she took to get there.

LEAD: Among the ''lush excesses'' of my own experience at Time Inc., where I was a reporter for Sports Illustrated in 1956, was breakfast at the bargaining table (''Time Inc. Means Business,'' by Lester Bernstein, Feb. 26). In those days, management and the Newspaper Guild (of which I was an active member) sat at a pristine, linen-draped table with a skyline view.

LEAD: Seeking to capture a new line of hotel business, a Long Island development company will build in Suffolk and Nassau Counties in the next several years four all-suite hotels designed for guests who want to spend more than just a night or two. Gary Krupnick, president of the Westwood Companies of Hauppauge, L.I., said construction would start this summer on the first, a 141-unit hotel at Aero Drive and Johnson Avenue, in Islip.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: SEVERAL years ago, when the virtuoso violinist Albert Markov toured here and abroad, he kept running into his neighbors. ''From Darien and Rowayton, my musical neighbors were there,'' he said.
LEAD: Although their subscription seasons have officialy ended, neither the Hartfordd nor the New Haven symphony is ready for summer vacation.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Boeing confirmed today that it would sell up to $512 million worth of 747 jumbo jets to South Africa in a deal that drew strong criticism from members of the state's Congressional delegation.

LEAD: An article in the Education Life section on April 9 about an elementary-school class in holography misstated the exposure time for a laser beam to produce a hologram, or three-dimensional image. It was 10 seconds.

LEAD: The juke joint is nameless, a shack made of unpainted boards sitting just off a county road surrounded by cotton fields. But inside, James McElroy, guitarist with Roosevelt Barnes and the Playboys, is shouting, ''It's star time!'' A stir ripples through the crowd packed into the shack's two front rooms as Roosevelt (Booby)

LEAD: SNUG HARBOR is no Provincetown, but within its cultural center is the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, where the focus is on artists who live or have their studios in Staten Island. At the moment, the Newhouse is taking inventory with its ''Staten Island Invitational,'' a show by 29 painters and sculptors, 2 ceramists and 1 photographer, all of whom have appeared here before.

LEAD: Satyajit Ray, Sidelined for more than half a decade by heart disease, is about to return to the cinema world with his 26th feature film - and first screen adaptation of a play, Henrik Ibsen's ''Enemy of the People.''

LEAD: MY grandfather will turn 100 next week. He is the same age as the Eiffel Tower and 100 years younger than the French Revolution. From the neighboring Cote d'Azur, from Paris, from all the provinces of France, from New York, from Virginia, from the French West Indies, the family will travel to the south of France to celebrate with him.

LEAD: It's not often that a distributor downplays its own release of a major film, but next month MCA Home Video, in what amounts to a secret operation, will issue Martin Scorsese's explosively controversial ''Last Temptation of Christ'' without so much as an announcement, let alone advertising and promotion.
LEAD: Holders of credit cards, take note: Now just may be the time to shop around to see if you are getting the best possible deal.
LEAD: A bare majority of the American public says President Bush should pardon Oliver L. North, according to a Gallup Poll conducted for Newsweek Magazine.

LEAD: The Pat Hearn Gallery once occupied the northwest corner of Sixth Street and Avenue B in Alphabet City. One of the slickest galleries of the now defunct East Village heyday, Hearn's prompted marvel when in the mid-1980's it moved even farther east to an even slicker location on Ninth Street between Avenues C and D.
LEAD: ''ENQUIRER GRASS TO GROW UNWATCHED. GARDENERS REJOICE.''

LEAD: TOURING the fortified towns, called bastides, in southwestern France, gives travelers a glimpse of medieval life and a chance to explore some of the earliest examples of urban planning, in a lovely rural setting.

LEAD: Time weighs heavily at Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount broker. Transactions are down and so are profits. The days of pre-crash trading volume have become a distant memory, and employees have been encouraged to take three-month ''sabbaticals'' at one-quarter pay or to work part time to cut costs.

LEAD: Herman Wouk's novelized version of World War II rumbles to an 11 1/2-hour close on ABC this week, beginning tonight at 8 with a three-hour episode. Here, surely, is a landmark in television excess. The tally so far: 18 hours of ''The Winds of War,'' which did very well in the ratings, and 18 hours of the first part of ''War and

LEAD: My father is one of the few people I know whose stationary bicycle doesn't double as a clothes rack. But then again, he's also one of the few people I know who keeps a special notebook in which he records the number of miles he rides each day. A recent 8 A.M. phone call heralded news that in two years he'd clocked enough miles to have pedaled from Virginia to Los Angeles and back.

LEAD: The Bush Administration announced on April 28 that it had concluded an agreement with Japan for the co-development of a new jet fighter called the FSX. The deal would transfer American airframe and electronic technology to Japan and transfer Japanese composite material technology back to the United States.
LEAD: A former ally of President Robert Mugabe started an opposition political party in Harare this week, the first new party to be formed in Zimbabwe since independence in 1980.

LEAD: GRAY SWEATS JUST DON'T CUT IT ANYMORE. THOSE who are serious about exercise - the ones with board-flat stomachs who visit spas once a year and health clubs once a day -are just as serious about dressing for action.

LEAD: On June morning in 1984, I drove by taxi from Beirut to Jerusalem. The Beirut taxi driver took me as far south as the Israeli army lines, about 25 miles from the border, where I had to get out with my suitcases and golf clubs and drag them through the Israeli checkpoint and down a stretch of road to link up with another Lebanese taxi that would take me to the

LEAD: A relaxation of antitrust laws is being given high-level consideration as a way to help American industry remain competitive in high technology. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said that in certain categories of high-tech products the Administration would favor an easing of antitrust laws that penalize corporations for cooperating with competitors.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Cashel of Boston and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Kerry Cashel, to William Watson Saltonstall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gurdon Saltonstall Jr. of Marion, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Abbie Hoffman gave away hundreds of thousands of dollars but left an estate worth only about $2,000, says his attorney, Gerald Lefcourt. ''It's not that he didn't take in a lot of money - it's just that he didn't keep it,'' Mr. Lefcourt said Thursday. Mr. Hoffman, 52 years old, killed himself April 12 in his apartment near New Hope, Pa.
LEAD: The African National Congress is standing firm, some would say intransigent, at a time when the political ground has begun shifting around Africa's oldest national liberation movement.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a participant last November in a T.W.A. Getaway tour to London, I agree with Stanley Carr (''Solo or Package?'' Travel, March 5) that there are definite cost advantages to package tours. But these savings can be expensive in the form of discomfort, sleepless nights and ruined vacations.

LEAD: Juliann Davidson and Marc Chusid were married yesterday at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Long Beach Island, N.J., by the Rev. William Rosenow. The Rev. Paul White, a Presbyterian minister, assisted. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Davidson 2d of Wayne, Pa., is the vice president of sales communication at MTV Networks in New York.
LEAD: The Punk Voice

LEAD: Jamie Mambro and Jay Williams, two advertising executives, are working to help the homeless here with a campaign to benefit the Pine Street Inn, a shelter that provides lodging, food and medical services for 1,200 men and women a day.

LEAD: Stand back - the superlatives are going to intersect here, the result of the long-overdue video releases of two classic screwball comedies by Howard Hawks, 20TH CENTURY (1934, RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video, $69.95) and BRINGING UP BABY (1938, Turner Home Video, $19.98).
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: New York City is not usually thought of as sylvan, but that's just what it is at this time of year. A street in Greenwich Village, for instance, is canopied with white blossoms, the pear trees on both sides having met and married in its center. The pink of cherry blossoms clashes with the red of old brick houses all over town, and magnolia trees are flaunting their last candles.

LEAD: Center field belongs to Len Dykstra. Besides his higher batting average, Dykstra's defensive abilities make him a Gold Glove contender. Wilson is a good backup for each outfield position. MONICA RESILLEZ Jackson Heights, Queens

LEAD: THERE are many reasons why the Lot, as well as the departments that spread out from its boundaries, has maintained a gastronomic culture all its own. This ocher-hued, rustic land offers no easy access to Paris, and even Bordeaux and Toulouse - the closest major cities - remain a world apart. The culinary richness of its farmers and independent country folk has remained relatively undiminished, as well as widely envied, by the rest of the country.

LEAD: BANANA DIPLOMACY: The Making of American Policy in Nicaragua, 1981-1987, by Roy Gutman. (Touch-stone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Step by step, a Newsday correspondent traces the decisions that led to the United States' entanglement with the Sandinistas and the contras. Last year our reviewer, Linda Robinson, said the book is ''superb journalism, asking the right questions and making crucial distinctions - rare qualities in this polarized debate.

LEAD: Tibetan exiles in Nepal, fearful that their country of refuge will grow more dependent on China because of an Indian economic blockade, say they are worried about their future in this land, where they are prohibited from taking part in anti-Chinese activities.

LEAD: B. Rajam Iyer is a distinguished South Indian singer and scholar who is appearing in the United States for the first time, courtesy of a spring teaching stint at Amherst College in Massachusetts. Friday night he sang at Washington Square Church under the auspices of the World Music Institute, and made one grateful for his presence if regretful that he had waited so long to perform here.
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY and Westchester County may share the sources of their drinking water, but the same cannot be said for their approaches to its use, especially during a drought.

LEAD: PRODDED by reports that the captain of the Exxon Valdez was drinking before the catastrophic oil spill, more people here are asking whether transportation workers should be randomly tested for the nation's most pervasive drug, alcohol, as well as illegal ones like cocaine and marijuana.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 10 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay enact the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 2 2 7 A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving.

LEAD: THE ladies' drink of the night is no longer Seven and Seven. It's Sex on the Beach. The lindy, stroll, frug, jerk, twist and hustle have given way to no-name dancing. ''Call it freestyle,'' shouts one dancer as he flails his arms and bends his knees.

LEAD: In Australia, Marilyn Quayle was briefed on floods and cyclones. In Java, she flew over active volcanoes and stalked killer insects in rice paddies. In Singapore, she sailed on a yacht around the harbor checking on oil tankers and contingency plans for spills. In Thailand, she discussed reforestation.

LEAD: WHAT do schoolteachers, police officers, sales clerks, secretaries, nurses, carpenters and accountants in New Jersey have in common? They all have a difficult time finding affordable housing. The problem is not new to the state. What is new is that New Jersey's lack of affordable housing now threatens the quality of life for many more of its residents.
LEAD: Weapons of war are tangible.

LEAD: Gen. Adnan Khairallah, Deputy Commander in Chief of Iraq's armed forces and Defense Minister, was killed on Friday in a helicopter crash in a sandstorm in northern Iraq, President Saddam Hussein said today. General Khairallah was 50 years old.

LEAD: About 130 Vietnamese refugees were massacred or left to drown last month by pirates who attacked their boat off the Malaysian coast, refugee officials said on Friday, citing the account of the only refugee known to have survived the ordeal.

LEAD: When the Williamsburgh Savings Bank opened its 29-story headquarters at One Hanson Place in 1929 it became the focal point of downtown Brooklyn and, at 512 feet, the tallest building on Long Island, from the East River to Montauk. The four-faced clock tower was the world's tallest and even larger than London's Big Ben.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about preschool programs misidentified the state agency providing a free booklet, ''Choosing a Child Care Center.'' The booklet is available from the Division of Youth and Family Services, 1 South Montgomery Street, CN 717, Trenton 08625.

LEAD: RECENTLY, a local church held its annual clothing drive, designed to bring relief to needy people in the area. Since ours is a family with six children - four sprouting lads and two hemline-conscious maidens - we have much to offer, and participate every year.
LEAD: Aiding Black Charities
LEAD: As collectors become swamped with new issues, they try to categorize their interests.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Johnny Ray drove in the go-ahead run with a single today as the California Angels rallied for two runs in the ninth inning and beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 5-4. It was the fourth victory in a row for the Angels and their ninth in 10 games.

LEAD: Religious symbols, icons and amulets are moving from the fringes to the mainstream of fashion jewelry. From Christian Lacroix's stylized crosses to the new-age crystals of Tina Chow to the talismans created by craft jewelers, there are choices for many tastes and budgets.

LEAD: On behalf of the Westchester County Hispanic Advisory Board, I commend you for your insightful article on the assertiveness of the Hispanic community to improve its status in Westchester County [ ''Hispanic Residents Striving for Political and Economic Gains,'' April 16 ] . We are pleased by your coverage and equally hopeful that in future editions the other issues presented in our report, ''Westchester Hispanics: An Agenda for County Action,'' will be closely examined, especially the considerable concern of quality education for

LEAD: What business do city officeholders have also holding time-consuming posts in political parties? None, in the view of Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., head of New York City's Charter Revision Commission, who would ban such behavior.

LEAD: The Athletics' Jose Canseco was far from Oakland and the major leagues yesterday, sitting in a 10,200-seat stadium in Alabama getting ready to play for the Huntsville Stars in a Southern League game.
LEAD: The young poet nervously recited his work, then spent several long moments in what must have seemed like purgatory until the critic finally spoke.

LEAD: THE proliferation of elections in Latin America and other places where democracy has a tenuous hold has led to a boom in business for election observers who check whether the process is free and fair.
LEAD: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: A robot submersible, transmitting video pictures to scientists and schoolchildren by way of its long tether and radio links, has revealed a field of hot geysers on the floor of the Mediterranean Sea 110 miles southwest of Naples.
LEAD: Syrian and Christian gunners plunged into heavy artillery duels across Beirut and in nearby hills today, ending a nine-day-old truce. The police said 10 people were killed and 33 wounded.
LEAD: Mack Lobell, holder of eight world records, easily won the Algo Scott Memorial harness race today.

LEAD: THE furor over New York State's decision to increase tax rates of wage earners from out of state has revived an issue that Alexander Hamilton had probably thought was settled with the signing of the Constitution.

LEAD: BLESSED with a majestic natural setting, this city has always prided itself on holding onto its quality of life even at the expense of business expansion. In the last two decades, half-built freeways were stopped in mid-construction, renovation plans for the pleasantly chaotic Pike Place Market were voted down, and parks were built on covered highways and old industrial sites.

LEAD: Ardent smokers at Penn State University say they will not hide their lights under bushels, in bathrooms or anywhere else for that matter in the face of a policy announced this month to ban smoking in virtually all university buildings and vehicles.

LEAD: The article on the German-American Bund (''Jerseyana,'' April 9), informative and interesting on the surface, offers an excellent example of misguided ''reasoning,'' replete with dangerous assumptions and conclusions lurking behind the facade of fair-seeming words.

LEAD: St. Mark's Anglican Church in Smith's Parish, Bermuda, was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kathryn Morgan Deane, a daughter of Marjorie S. Deane and Disque D. Deane of New York, Greenwich, Conn., and Tuckerstown, Bermuda, to Richard T. Krantz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Krantz of New York and Boca Raton, Fla.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NASSAU County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a candidate this year for the ninth time in the last 15 years, probably has shaken more hands and mailed more letters to constituents than any Nassau politician on the scene today.

LEAD: Margaret Elizabeth Hicks and Charles Broadfoot Holmes were married last evening at St. James Episcopal Church in Wilmington, N.C. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Cook and the Rt. Rev. Thomas Henry Wright, who retired as the Episcopal Bishop of the Eastern Diocese of North Carolina and is the bride's great-uncle.

LEAD: Susan Ward Bunnell, a daughter of LeRoy H. Bunnell Jr. of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Barbara Grove Bunnell, was married yesterday to Arthur Harold Tildesley Jr., a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Arthur H. Tildesley of Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. and the bridegroom's father officiated at St.

LEAD: Perry J. Watkins made it no secret that he was gay when he was drafted in 1967, but the Army said he could be discharged only after homosexual activity was proved. By 1984, Mr. Watkins was a sergeant with an exemplary record, a career soldier like his father. But the Army discharged him under a rule change which said that avowed homosexuality barred military service.

LEAD: CALIFORNIA still has the jump on the rest of the country when it comes to pioneering America's revolution in food and drink. Lately the state has turned its attention to beer; the repeal in 1976 of a Prohibition-era law against homebrewing has allowed a new generation of homebrewers and microbreweries to flourish.

LEAD: Frank (Bud) Kelley, one of the first Americans to fly a jet airplane, died Wednesday after suffering a stroke. He was 74 years old. As a test pilot for the Bell Aircraft Corporation, Mr. Kelley flew an early jet, the XP-59, on Nov. 16, 1942, over Muroc Dry Lake in the Mojave Desert, said Donald S.

LEAD: The warrens and alleyways of the Nablus casbah are desolate and still. For the fifth straight day, the 20,000 Arab residents of the ancient market are under curfew, locked in their homes night and day as punishment for the killing of an Israeli soldier a few days earlier. But as Moshiko Giat, a reserve paratrooper, and the seven other members of his patrol move through the narrow twisting corridors, pressing themselves tight against walls, pointing their automatic rifles around every corner before they turn, it's clear they feel a strong threatening presence.

LEAD: THE issue of race came up last week in Lynette Grande's third-grade class. ''We were talking about it,'' Mrs. Grande said, ''and I asked the kids whether they thought of me as their teacher or as their black teacher. They thought about it.''
LEAD: Kevin G. McGuire has been a paraplegic since he was 7 years old, when a drunken driver veered onto the baseball field where he was playing. But he has always held fast to his hopes and dreams.

LEAD: Antony Gormley is both director and actor on a sculptural stage as spare as anything in Beckett. He is the mind deciding where his figures will go, and he is the body from which his squatting, flying and tumbling figures are cast in plaster and then fixed in lead. Even when there are two figures and they seem to be a man and woman in sexual union, the molds were taken from him alone.
LEAD: The word spa is dusted with a bit of magic.

LEAD: The Cavendish Club's Invitational Charity Pairs, one of the world's strongest annual events, will be slightly different this year. There will be 40 pairs instead of 36, and play next weekend will be at the Westbury Hotel, 69th Street and Madison Avenue instead of the host club.

LEAD: IN 1979, SHORTLY AFTER THE Oakland (Calif.) Museum put on display a Rand McNally globe of ocean-floor relief, Pierina R. Nicholson, an associate curator of earth sciences, noticed what she thought was an error in the definition of the Amazon River delta. ''So I got a map of the coast and it verified my instinct,'' she recalls, and thus she was off on a project that 10 years later remains at least a year and a half from completion - the first globe to present an accurate, scientific rendition of the world's ocean floor.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dodsley Walker of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Starr Walker, to Andre Robert Wyss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Wyss of Manhattan Beach, Calif. A July wedding is planned. Miss Walker, a research assistant at the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory of Columbia University, is a graduate of the Chapin School and the University of Colorado at Boulder.

LEAD: ''Eyewitness: The 32d Annual World Press Photo Contest Award-Winning Photographs'' can be seen at the Nikon House Gallery in Rockefeller Center through May 20. The 100 photographs were judged the best of the entries from 1,295 photographers, publications and press agencies of 62 participating countries.
LEAD: When his baby's eyes dimmed, Rudy Linares cradled the limp child in his arms and ran terrified through the streets to a firehouse, shouting tearfully, ''Help me! Help me! My baby is dying.''
LEAD: A Harlem-based philanthropic organization has edged out the United Way for the right to solicit contributions from 73,000 Federal employees working in New York City.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Sarah Palmer Bower, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Bower of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Paul Herbert Maenner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Maenner of Omaha. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church.
LEAD: THE ENCHANTED GLASSBritain and Its Monarchy. By Tom Nairn. 414 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Paper, $12.95.

LEAD: They work in a sliver of a storefront in SoHo and create ceramic pieces - espresso cups, platters, dinnerware, teapots and vases - with an innovative twist. Lanie Cecula, 37 years old, and her husband, Marek, 45, who own Contemporary Porcelain, settled in their shop at 105 Sullivan Street (between Spring and Prince Streets) in 1976.
LEAD: Maggy Sterner and Robert L. Drogin were married last evening at Bargemusic, a floating chamber-music hall at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn. Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenik officiated.

LEAD: I felt the same embarrassment Donald I. Fine did when my father, his ever present Voigtlander camera swinging from its strap, tried to get me to stand next to Al Jolson so that he could take our picture in front of a hotel in Miami, Fla. (About Men: ''The Boy in the Photograph,'' April 2). The smiling ''Jolie'' even offered me a nickel to pose with him.

LEAD: IN his art of around 1908, Matisse was inspired, he said, by his children's crude attempts at drawing. What his children probably liked was the kind of images now being shown by the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook under the title, ''Childhood Enchantments.''

LEAD: AFTER several failed experiments earlier in the decade, the newspaper industry all but abandoned its quest to develop electronic systems that would allow subscribers to read the news on a home video screen. Now newspapers and other vendors of information are being upstaged by the telephone companies, which are seeking to stake their claim in the emerging field of electronic publishing.
LEAD: In 1971, Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez seized power in Bolivia and ruled for seven years, jailing thousands of opponents and exiling others.

LEAD: The Washington State Fruit Commission, a trade association of growers, has withdrawn $71,300 worth of television advertising for Northwest cherries from three CBS affiliates to protest a recent news report about Alar.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: John N. Turner's decision to step down as leader of Canada's Liberal Party has given the political opposition a window for renewal that may not open again for several years.

LEAD: This is the kind of place you leave reluctantly, looking back. There are shops with bells on the doors. Roads that wind past grazing horses. And yard sales where children set up shop in a wagon and sell homemade cookies for a quarter.

LEAD: A 30-year-old Queens man suspected in 29 robberies at knifepoint, mostly of senior citizens, was arrested and charged with eight of the robberies last night.

LEAD: Investigators have concluded that James W. Hall 3d, an Army warrant officer court-martialed earlier this year for espionage, severely damaged several electronic eavesdropping operations aimed at Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, Government officials say.

LEAD: BEGINNING this month and continuing through the next year, voters in more than a dozen Latin American countries will be going to the polls to render judgment on a decade of hardship. Though the 1980's have been marked by the disappearance of military dictatorship and the emergence of democratic civilian rule in one country after another, that shift, like the coming cycle of presidential elections, has occurred against a backdrop of a continentwide economic crisis that has left the people disenchanted and newly implanted institutions vulnerable.
LEAD: THE BEGINNING OF SPRING By Penelope Fitzgerald. 187 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: IF a stranded motorist in Westchester is lucky enough to find a phone, the hard part is still to come: determining how to get help when there are 145 different police, fire and emergency medical services in the county, each with its own jurisdiction.
LEAD: After five years of postponed hopes and a dramatic appeal from 100 schoolchildren at City Hall last year, lower Manhattan has a library of its own.
LEAD: This small rural community is challenging longstanding voting rules of the Benevolent and Protective Order of the Elks on the ground that it promotes racial discrimination.

LEAD: AND they're off. Trotting down the runway with eyes stuck on watches and hands filled with coffee cups, briefcases and newspapers, they pant toward the whistle. Nobody smiles, nobody talks, nobody looks at anybody.

LEAD: A SEVEN-FOOT-TALL wigwam, stands at the center of the new permanent exhibit that will open this afternoon at the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History in Storrs. The exhibit is the latest development at a museum which, at seven years old, is growing and thriving despite lacking its own building.

LEAD: THE flashing red lights of the school bus demanded that I stop. As the children manuevered down that last large step, they absent-mindedly went their separate directions home. The afternoon was sunny and warm. The lights turned off and the line of cars proceeded.

LEAD: The marriage of Joyce Elena de Napoli, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Anthony de Napoli of Harrison, N.Y., to Michael Patrick McNiff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick McNiff of Brooklyn, took place yesterday in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Leslie J. Ivers performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection.

LEAD: WITHOUT a day to waste, employees of the state's Department of Transportation, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and Conrail, plus private consultants and contractors, are working at a relentless pace to raise the vertical clearances at bridges crossing the Hudson rail line from Westchester to Albany County by Aug.
LEAD: ENCLOSING an interior doorway by sheathing it with wallboard is an easy remodeling project. It is also a good way to gain experience for more extensive wall remodeling.

LEAD: Becoming pregnant at the height of the dress-for-success look in 1982 nearly squelched Rebecca C. Matthias's budding career. Helping to start a computer company in Boston, Ms. Matthias, then 28 years old, searched in vain for appropriate attire for her calls on local bankers.

LEAD: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, Laura G. S. Farrand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Farrand of Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Charles Rene Cachera by the Rev. John Andrew.

LEAD: CHINA'S six-decade civil war may be ending. The bearer of the olive branch was Shirley Kuo, Finance Minister in the Taiwan Government, who last week became the first Nationalist official to return to China since the Communist victory in 1949.

LEAD: NEXT Saturday, I'll be driving out to Long Island to take part in the 25th reunion of my graduating class from high school. The event is one to which I am looking forward with mixed feelings - much like the mixed feelings with which I approached high school itself so many years ago.

LEAD: An article on April 9 (''Two Colleges With No Room for the Selfish'') reported that beginning next fall, Eastern Connecticut State University will be the second school in the state university system to require volunteer labor of students in order to qualify for a dormitory room.

LEAD: One of the nice things about hearing period-instrument concerts these days is that the instruments themselves are generally well played and less of an issue than they used to be. This is by way of saying that when the Mozartean Players came to the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night, Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn were more on our minds than what they were being played on.

LEAD: The marriage of Joan Waugh Harney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Selby Harney of Hilton Head Island, S.C., to Dr. John Christopher Wiles, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Gordon P. Wiles of East Lyme, Conn., took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in East Lyme. The Rev. Steven E. Hulme officiated.

LEAD: At least three Palestinians were killed and more than 138 others were shot and wounded today during the most violent day of rioting in the Gaza Strip since the Palestinian uprising began 17 months ago.

LEAD: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane.

LEAD: The first half of ''Quasi-Kinetics,'' presented by Otrabanda at La Mama Annex on Thursday night, is like an endless evening spent with one of the ruling-class bores who populate New Yorker cartoons. In the theater-dance piece, written and directed by Roger Babb, a man and a woman talk exhaustively of appearances and the way they see each other.

LEAD: Cynthia Joanne Rodgers, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Barclay Rodgers Jr. of Delmar, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Miles Belgorod, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Belgorod of New York. John A. Greco, an Episcopal archdeacon, officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.

LEAD: On behalf of my team, I'd like to thank Mr. Shainberg for his discussion of archery. Finding the zone is a goal in itself for many archers, transcending competition and score. For many of us, archery is not only a sport but a spiritual exercise, the results of which - relaxation, improved concentration and better mental discipline -carry over into our daily lives.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: More than a quarter of a century ago, before all a Russian athlete wanted out of an American sports tour was a few pairs of blue jeans, Valery Brumel, then the holder of the world high-jump record, was in New York for an indoor track meet at Madison Square Garden. While on display at a track writers luncheon, he was asked where he had purchased the elegantly colorful sweater he was wearing.

LEAD: CULTURE IMAGES An exhibition of almost 100 framed and captioned photographs from the collection of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Manhattan will be on display for one week at Abbott House in Irvington. Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist and author, will open the exhibition at 1:30 P.M.

LEAD: LITIGATING suits for surviving family members after someone dies in an airplane accident is a highly specialized area of the law. Wherever the crash and wherever the trial, the same lawyers are likely to battle over responsibility for the deaths and how much the victims might have earned had they lived.

LEAD: THE 1968 HemisFair tower is still the tallest structure in San Antonio, but 10 blocks away workers are putting the finishing touches on an office high-rise that will be the city's tallest commercial building.
LEAD: ABC Sports announced today that it had reached agreement to televise the three Triple Crown races through 1992.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet danced only two works on Friday night at the New York State Theater: George Balanchine's ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet,'' in its first performance of the season, and a repeat performance of Jerome Robbins's ''Goldberg Variations.'' But no one could complain that the program was flimsy.

LEAD: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane.

The concert will be given twice, on Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M., and will include Mozart's Wind Serenade in E flat, Schoenberg's Chamber Symphony and Mr. Kirchner's Piano Trio.

KEMP, THE FRESHLY MINTED Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was stabbing forcefully at a plate of lasagna in a Baltimore soup kitchen when Bryant Cochrane, a young black man who said he was homeless, pushed through a crowd to beard the famous visitor. Cochrane wore a blue T-shirt and sneakers;

LEAD: If the Canadian Center for Architecture were just a bit better known, and if it cast its net wider to include all of the visual arts, then it might just be confused with the Getty Museum in California. For the Canadian Center, like the Getty, is an immensely ambitious museum and research center, financed by the foresight of a single donor.
LEAD: There are startling similarities between an American Presidential campaign and a papal voyage like the nine-day African trip that Pope John Paul II completed today in this capital.

LEAD: One week ago, the Yankees traded away a significant part of their pitching future. Today, as a sudden snowstorm blew through town and temperatures fell toward freezing, they faced a problem that eventually could make them regret the deal.

LEAD: One might not think a 50-degree temperature and a thick cloud cover is swimming weather, especially for students who are supposed to be in class. LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Zaccaro of Forest Hills, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter Donna Anne Zaccaro to Paul Arthur Ullman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ullman of St. Louis. The couple plan to marry in October.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SOME come for the thrills. Paddling madly, they raft the Gauley River's Pillow Rock rapid, dropping 25 feet in 20 yards, and shoot through Lost Paddle - a half mile of the highest-rated rapids run by commercial outfitters anywhere - and plunge 14 feet into Devil's Hole at Pure Screaming Hell.
LEAD: The Flyers, who like to cause trouble, are in it.
LEAD: Vyacheslav Ekimov of the Soviet Union overcame punishing hills and treacherous terrain to win the first stage of the inaugural Tour de Trump bicycle race this afternoon.

LEAD: What Lawrence Shainberg is talking about in his article is a realization of the Tao, an attainment of oneness, the arrival at the simple truth. The phenomenon is not just experienced by world-class athletes, nor is it reached only from within the arena of sports.

LEAD: Fifteen stories above Fifth Avenue, Earl Reiback has planted more than 500 petunias, impatiens, pansies and other flowering plants that will transform his terrace into a garden worthy of a country estate.
LEAD: Howard Johnson celebrated his one-week anniversary as the No. 2 hitter in the Mets' lineup yesterday by doing what he has done since he became the No. 2 hitter. He produced a big hit.

LEAD: A Manhattan town house designed by Philip Johnson in 1949 for Blanchette Rockefeller, the wife of John D. Rockefeller 3d, was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's for $3.5 million. The brick-walled converted 1860's carriage house at 242 East 52d Street was bought by an unidentified foreign buyer, competing with eight other people - several Americans and at least one

LEAD: Christina Petrowska, a Canadian pianist, presented a program of contemporary music Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall. It was an evening full of worthy composers and not uninteresting pieces. But there was a curious sameness to the music, one that seemed to speak as much of Miss Petrowksa's sensibility as it did of the composers.

LEAD: Patricia G. Canan and Charles R. Canan of Rochester have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Ellen Canan and John H. Grady Jr., a son of Mrs. John H. Grady of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Grady.

LEAD: FROM TIME TO TIME, NOT INTENDING TO, I imagine myself in charge of my own body. It's a faintly unpleasant sensation: sitting there in the cockpit, worrying whether everything is operational. The scariest part, easily, is the stomach.
LEAD: Todd Benzinger hit a go-ahead single in the fifth inning and Paul O'Neill and Ron Oester drove in two runs each tonight as the Cincinnati Reds rallied and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-4.

LEAD: Let's finally put Iran-contra behind us and get on with the business of government. That sentiment is proclaimed most loudly by supporters of Oliver North but is heard on all sides. That will not happen soon, nor can it, for this monumental affair is about government's most important business.

LEAD: Lawrence T. Gresser, a retired judge of the Queens Criminal Court, died of heart disease on Monday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Atlantis, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in retirement in Lake Worth, Fla., and on Shelter Island, L.I.

LEAD: As a law enforcement officer, I have reached the zone that Lawrence Shainberg describes - albeit only in later years - particularly when I have been working with younger, more excitable officers in life-threatening situations. It seems as if time slows down, sometimes frighteningly so - so that everything becomes clear, and I make no errors.
LEAD: ''To tell the American people that if all you do is open these barriers to markets, the trade deficit will go away, that is not true.'' Carla A. Hills, U.S. trade representative.

LEAD: Until recently, the people of this small town in the southwest corner of Mississippi didn't see much in common between themselves and Shakespeare. They read his plays in school and left it at that. But when the Cornerstone Theater Company showed up and started building a stage in their local movie house, Shakespeare became the talk of the town.

LEAD: At one end of the conference hall a scientist stood in front of a video screen, doing what appeared to be a feeble attempt at break dancing. LEAD: Auto Racing Senna Gains Pole Spot: The world Formula One champion, Ayrton Senna of Brazil, gained the pole position for the Monaco Grand Prix as he blistered the Monte Carlo streets in a qualifying best in the second practice session yesterday. Senna toured the twisting, 2.068-mile circuit in 1 minute 22.308 seconds.
LEAD: The Knicks went through a 90-minute practice yesterday at their SUNY-Purchase training camp and switched their concentration from the Chicago Bulls to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

LEAD: ''ALL of us who work with her are convinced that were it not for her calling, she would surely be the head of a Fortune 500 company today,'' said Marge Lovero, director of the Entrepreneurial Center at Manhattanville College here.

''We thought God - a man; our father - a man,'' she said. ''Anything with authority was male, even in the household.

Reformed Church to Robert Roelofs Verbrugge, the son of Helen R. Verbrugge of St. Paul and the late Dr. Frank Verbrugge. The Rev. Frank Piazza officiated. Mrs. Verbrugge is a marketing director at Advanced Care Products, a manufacturer of health-care products in Raritan, N.J., and her husband is a district manager at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in Bridgewater, N.J.

LEAD: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, a former player with the Knicks, will deliver the eulogy tomorrow at a memorial service for Larry Fleisher, the former head of the National Basketball Players Association. The service will be held at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, at 11:30 A.M.

There were also cheers for such rival old-timers as Bobby Richardson and Curt Flood, who got three hits apiece, and Bill Mazeroski and Joe
LEAD: THE LOST FATHER By Marina Warner. 318 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

LEAD: ''My finances are in shambles,'' the diary entry reads. ''With what unbelievable folly have I so long ignored them and let them drift. In my 30th year, I was the richest young man in town. In my 50th - well, I'm driving a 10-year-old car, owe so God-awful much money I'll need luck to pay it off. ''But I will, somehow I will.

LEAD: For about 10,000 disadvantaged children from New York City, images of steaming concrete and open fire hydrants will be replaced this summer by flowered fields and cooling ponds because of the Fresh Air Fund, which begins its 113th fund-raising campaign today.

LEAD: For brides-to-be who do not want to wear a traditional wedding gown because they do not want to look frilly and demure, there is another option: the bridal suit. It is also the outfit of choice for many women who are marrying for the second time or in an intimate ceremony.

LEAD: I AM not sure whether I've just been lucky with my mailmen or if all letter carriers are the interested, caring people both of mine have been. I do know that the two men who have delivered my mail over the 38 years I've lived in the same house have indeed been special deliverers.

LEAD: Sunday Silence scored a two-and-a-half-length upset victory over Easy Goer in the 115th Kentucky Derby today at Churchill Downs, but the only thing that seemed right about the race was that the two best colts beat the others.

After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Englert of Centerville, Mass., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Gretchen Elise Englert, and David Harold Neal, the son of Mrs. Harold Neal Jr. of Stuart, Fla., and the late Mr. Neal.

LEAD: Women are finally emerging as forces to contend with in the theater, says the playwright Tina Howe. They can write as feminists, says Ntozake Shange, and they can try to present a uniquely female perception of the world - a world in which their reality has often been illegitimate, or silent. They can, says Cindy Lou Johnson, try to understand in some way what goes on between men and women.

LEAD: Chris Blyseth is sitting next to me, trying to accommodate his 6-foot-6-inch frame to the Chevy Corsica's average American bucket seat. In back, Jose Musso is talking about the car and what he, Chris and seven other members of their team have done to it.
LEAD: The United States is preparing to cut off economic assistance to the Sudan, one of the most underdeveloped countries on the continent and a major aid recipient in Africa.

LEAD: GOLDILOCKS. By Andrew Coburn. (Scribner's, $17.95.) Crime novels - unlike mysteries, which usually rely heavily on plot - are successful largely due to their interesting characters and their mood of psychological tension. The most effective, like those by Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler, create sinister worlds we don't mind visiting, but certainly wouldn't care to live in.

LEAD: A picture last Sunday with an article about the United Nations' special representative for Namibia was captioned erroneously by The Associated Press and published in error as a result. It showed Lieut. Gen. D. Prem Chand, commander of the United Nations military force in Namibia, not Martti Ahtisaari, the special representative.
LEAD: I WAS TALKING BUSINESS with a colleague late one afternoon when the first call came. The voice on the other end was loud and panicked; my colleague looked over at me, horrified.
LEAD: Dan Majerle, the Phoenix Suns rookie guard who was a distant runner-up to Golden State's Mitch Richmond in this year's rookie of the year voting, got a little satisfaction today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: OPENING a new restaurant is an act of faith, and in the last few years there have been a number of such acts along Washington Street in South Norwalk. The latest is Cafe Parfait, an informal storefront restaurant lodged a few doors from the corner of South Main Street.

LEAD: A lot goes on at once in ''Outside the Law,'' presented by the Irondale Ensemble Project on Wednesday night at the Rapp Arts Center. The group, which also works with troubled children in the New York City school system, has woven a populist telling of the story of the notorious bank robber Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd and a little topical satire into the fabric of Shakespeare's ''As You Like It.

LEAD: The Washington Square Contemporary Music Series presented a concert Wednesday night at Weill Recital Hall of a Wisconsin-based string quartet with a San Francisco-flavored program. Of Washington Square or even New York, there was precious little; of interesting music, there was a fair amount.

LEAD: A great ball team is like an ensemble company: the best players in there every day, at the same position, learning to play together as a unit. Players do best when they are happy with their jobs and feel that management has a total commitment to them, even when they're in a slump. The platoon system may seem expedient on paper, but it does not work in the hearts of dedicated players or fans.

Dewey Thruway and Palisades Interstate Parkway - transit it. It is also the site of the Nanuet Mall, the county's largest shopping center, with 120 stores anchored by Sears and
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-23
LEAD: To the Editor: On snow-bright days in winter this Vermonter, transplanted to Michigan, wishes she were close enough to ''skip school'' to Smuggler's Notch.

LEAD: The judge in the trial of Matthew Barnwell, a Bronx elementary-school principal charged with buying two vials of crack, has ordered the jury to continue its deliberations today, despite a note from jurors indicating a deadlock.

LEAD: Liberals were wary and conservatives were elated when C. Everett Koop, an opponent of abortion, became the Surgeon General of the United States in 1981. Last week, some liberals probably moaned and some conservatives no doubt sighed with relief when he announced that he would resign in July. The 72-year-old pediatrician led attacks against smoking and the AIDS epidemic.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Gene Bass of Jericho, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Andrea Faith Bass and Joel David Orris, a son of Ruth Schwartz of Springfield, N.J., and the late John L. Orris.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $12.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in ''The Gunslinger.'' 2 5 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family between the two world wars.

LEAD: NEW ENGLAND'S unique supply of early American architecture has generated something of a growth industry in preservation. Antique houses are being acquired in increasing numbers, dismantled clapboard by clapboard, numbered and catalogued down to the last fireplace brick, strap hinge and beaded molding, then rebuilt across town or even in another state.

LEAD: There were times last year when Michael Chang was reduced to a footnote in the Andre Agassi story. Agassi had flair - a punk rock hairdo and equally colorful personality -plus a game that vaulted him to six tournament titles and No. 3 in the world. Chang preferred a brush cut and an impassive expression on the court, masking his emotions.

LEAD: In ''New Cities,'' performed by the Talking Band at La Mama, music is bread, not the food of love, for a string quartet on a world concert tour. A problem is that the bread provides not much sustenance most of the time for the weary and homesick musicians.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The splendid article by John Stone on ''Why Some Hands Get So Cold'' had one important omission (Body and Mind, March 12). The application of biofeedback techniques allows the patient literally to warm up cold fingers by releasing the spasm of the artery in the hand. Patients are conditioned to observe the changes on a sensitive thermometer so that they master the ability to increase the finger teperature.
LEAD: IT has taken 30 years to do it, but Jerrold A. Lieberman and Peter Brock have come along to develop a long ignored residential site in the Rego Park section of Queens.

LEAD: For 80 years, students at Miami University of Ohio sang a school song that included phrases like, ''Thy sons have quested from thee.'' In that time, those sons went off to fight in two World Wars and battles in Korea and Vietnam. But for 89 years, daughters, too, have attended Miami, and a little war has been fought and won to convince the university of their contributions.

LEAD: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane.

LEAD: L. J. Davis's article about Philip Morris Companies and their search for new fields wherein to invest their vast profits reminded me of the cocaine drug barons and their search for ways to launder their poison profits (''Philip Morris's Big Bite,'' April 9). The Surgeon General of the United States has labeled tobacco an addictive drug, so there is indeed more than a casual similarity.

LEAD: One of Time Inc.'s failed publications was not listed in your article. That magazine was called Letters. It started as a free eight-page supplement to Time to accommodate the overflow of letters to the editor. When it reached 20 pages, ads were solicited. In 1937, three years after it started, circulation reached 25,000 a year.

LEAD: WEAPON by Robert Mason (Putnam, $18.95) has an unusual and amusing premise. Meet Solo, a $2 billion robot designed for the Army by a brilliant American. Solo is going to be the ultimate soldier. He is packed full of gadgetry that gives him amazing strength and speed. He reads codes, picks up transmissions from space satellites and has his own kind of intelligence.

LEAD: The Accused 1988. Paramount Home Video. 1 hour, 50 minutes. $89.95. Laser disk (Image Entertainment), $34.95. Closed captioned. R. Jodie Foster won an Oscar as the victim of a boozy gang rape in the back room of a bar. Kelly McGillis is Katheryn Murphy, the assistant district attorney who, after letting the rapists plea bargain their way to lesser charges, prosecutes three of the witnesses on grounds that they actively encouraged the assault.
LEAD: On Aug. 2, it will be 10 years since Thurman Munson, the Yankee catcher, was killed while practicing landings and takeoffs at the Canton-Akron Airport in Canton, Ohio, where he lived.
LEAD: Trying to reverse the decline in voter turnout, Congress is advancing a bill that would allow people to register by mail and other means. Page 33.

LEAD: A plane carrying American tourists crash-landed in a remote jungle of the Yucatan Peninsula, killing 6 people and injuring 10, officials said today.

LEAD: YEARS ago, there were matchmakers who arranged for young men and women to meet the perfect marriage partner. Today, as singles bars and pages of personal ads attest, it seems even more difficult to meet that special someone.

LEAD: A quick and easy Sunday meal is flank steak glazed with maple mustard, accompanied by potatoes with broccoli and onions. And putting the grocery store to work as a sous-chef takes much drudgery out of preparing this, or any other, meal.

Others, like pilgrims of the Middle Ages, visit the sacred places; nowadays, less often the sacred places of religion than of art or politics.

LEAD: 200 YEARS OF QUILTS Among the events scheduled to celebrate Fairfield's 350th birthday is a joint exhibition at the historical society and the public library called ''Sunbursts, Baby Blocks and Crazy Quilts: Two Centuries of the Quiltmaking Art in Fairfield.''

LEAD: THE recent awarding of New York State scholarships to high school seniors by a rating system of combined S.A.T. (Scholastic Aptitude Test) scores and grade-point averages has aroused strong criticism from many Long Island school districts.

LEAD: ''MASS APPEAL'' is one of the decade's few American plays that homogenizes the ingredients for popular and artistic success. The play was the work of a 29-year-old playwright when it was first produced in 1980, and it manages to be as thoughtful as it is entertaining.

LEAD: E. Robert Wallach sat wordless in a Manhattan courtroom last week while a Federal prosecutor read a torrent of Mr. Wallach's printed words into the record of the latest corruption trial involving the Wedtech Corporation.

But the luncheon held last Wednesday at the Rumsey Playfield in the park was a special occasion, the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards, and those who attended did some serious suiting up.

Billhardt of New Canaan, Conn., were married yesterday at Grace United Methodist Church in Baltimore by the Rev. Dr. Frank Edward Trotter Jr. Mrs. Billhardt, an accountant at Arthur Andersen & Company in Stamford, Conn., graduated from the University of Richmond, as did her husband, a co-owner of Four Seasons Farm, a fruit and produce market in Darien, Conn.

LEAD: Few people enter a theater hoping to hate the movie, but, having paid their seven bucks, they don't take kindly to insult. Movie patrons are a prickly, unreliable lot. Friends one minute, adversaries the next. They want to believe, and they do believe, sometimes doggedly, until that moment when belief becomes insupportable.

LEAD: RUTH DUCKWORTH'S serene porcelain forms are matte white, eggshell thin and precise. In contrast, Albert Paley's decorative ironwork seems to exert an inner energy as its dark and twisted rods culminate in whiplash swirls. Works by these two internationally known craft artists are featured in an exhibition on view at the College Art Gallery of Montclair State

LEAD: For This Week: Feed new rosebushes with a well-balanced fertilizer or use commercial plant food; follow the label directions carefully. Last call to sow seed of calendula and bachelor buttons where they are to bloom in the garden. If the soil is warm, plant seeds of beans, corn and cucumbers.
LEAD: David R. Kotok's recent article, ''Inflation's Threat to Pensions'' (Opinion page), does not address the problem of an insufficient cost-of-living allowance in the New Jersey pension system.
LEAD: A winery worker accused of killing his wife, two of their daughters and four other people pleaded not guilty Friday to charges that could send him to the gas chamber.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MOST people never dream of packing rain slickers and woolen gloves for midsummer shoreline vacations. Nor do they relish the idea of waking at 4 A.M. But fishermen, neophyte and seasoned alike, flock to the central Oregon coast in the hope of catching some of the state's prized salmon and crustaceans.
LEAD: Faced with steadily dropping voter turnouts, Congress is advancing a sweeping proposal that would make it much easier for Americans to register to vote.

LEAD: In spring a young person's fancy turns to steeplechasing. So popular is the sport now that not even heavy rains could stop thousands of students at the University of Virginia, and many alumni, from traveling five miles last week to attend the Foxfield Races, the main spring event here, both as spectators and, in one case, as a jockey.

LEAD: What's up in women's hairstyles at the University of Miami is, well, hair - in stiff, spirited ponytails that look like palm trees sprouting atop the head. The stiffeners of choice include scrunchers, crunchers and plain old wool.

LEAD: He has been in the major leagues for only a month, but Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners has had a candy bar named after him. The Ken Griffey Jr. Milk Chocolate Bar wrapper will sport 1 of 12 different images of the center fielder in action, according to the distributor, Mike Cramer.

LEAD: AMID the fanfare of trumpets, guests in formal attire with brightly plumed masks, strolling musicians and mythological creatures including a griffin and a 27-foot dragon, a Renaissance feast was recently held to benefit the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia seem to be converging on a workable deal for their country when Vietnam ends its occupation in the fall. Into this welcome development comes a proposal by Representative Stephen Solarz, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia, to send military aid to non-Communist rebels in a coalition led by the Prince but dominated by the dreaded Khmer Rouge.

LEAD: FIFTEEN years ago this spring a tornado raced through this rural county seat near Dayton, killing 32 people, leveling homes and devastating much of downtown. While residential areas were quickly rebuilt, downtown redevelopment took a different course because city leaders realized the tornado had created an opportunity to rebuild.

LEAD: For four years, Lenny Dykstra and Mookie Wilson have platooned in center field for the Mets with productive results. But the time has come to give Dykstra the chance to prove he can be the everyday center fielder. Given the chance, I feel he can hit left-handed pitching. Wilson is a streak hitter and a good fourth outfielder.
LEAD: tr,br1WITH JUSTICE FOR NONE Destroying an American Myth. By Gerry Spence. 370 pp. New York: Times Books. $18.95.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Smith 4th of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Chatham, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter Kelley MacGregor Smith to Peter John Mongeau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice G. Mongeau of Attleboro, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: Every coin collector looks for mint errors on coins. Even the young collector will look to see if there is a miss-strike or double-strike on a cent or nickel. The days of finding a three-legged buffalo are perhaps over - more recent coins fill our pockets - but still the search continues. One extremely rare error is the brockage.
LEAD: Lawrence Shainberg's article ''Finding 'The Zone' '' (April 9) interested me greatly. I believe that it explains what can happen to even your common, garden-variety walker.

LEAD: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane.

LEAD: These days the word from Wall Street is hardly cheery. The profitability drought has produced almost daily reports of layoffs, not to mention word that businesses are being cut back or even eliminated.
LEAD: Immigration officials from the United States and Britain are considering tightening security by conducting immigration checks before passengers board airplanes, American officials say.

LEAD: IT was once Coney Island's Statue of Liberty, an impressive symbol beckoning to passing oceanliners. But now the Half Moon Hotel, having spent its waning years as the Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center nursing home, is scheduled for demolition as soon as the home completes a new building.
LEAD: WHAT ARE WE going to call the decade after the decade of the Nineties?''

LEAD: Three years ago it would have been unthinkable for Marion Copenhaver, a state legislator here, to do what she did last month: urge a cutoff of state money for the Christa McAuliffe planetarium, a monument to the Concord teacher who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

LEAD: Ryszard Kapuscinski's article, ''Uganda: After the Terror'' (March 12), is a devastating portrait of the legacy of killing, torture, looting and harassment that took place during the regimes of Milton Obote and Idi Amin.
LEAD: The letter from Herbert Jaffe [ ''Power Panaceas Are a Delusion,'' March 26 ] supporting Shoreham is the usual cry from a speculator trying to rescue an unwise investment.

LEAD: They should play Lenny Dykstra in center and Mookie Wilson in right. They are both better players than Darryl Strawberry. Look what happened to Lou Gehrig: He was sitting on the bench, Wally Pipp got sick, Lou went in and Pipp never played first base again for the Yankees. If a man can hit and field, he must play and not sit on the bench.
LEAD: More than 50 dogs were the guests of honor at a book party in Central Park Thursday evening and they seemed to get along at least as well as people do at most cocktail parties.

LEAD: In the early 1980's, state-owned British Airways P.L.C. was known for its service - infamously so. One well-worn joke was that B.A. stood for ''bloody awful.''

LEAD: When Bob Mould was Husker Du's guitarist, his songs arrived in a blur of power chords and punky, doubletime drumming. Husker Du broke up after its 1987 album ''Warehouse,'' and on Mr. Mould's new solo album, ''Workbook,'' his music has taken on Celtic overtones, with modal tunes and a measured, marchlike pace.

LEAD: Norma McCorvey sat in a downtown diner here, eating lunch and talking of her life as ''Jane Roe,'' the pseudonym she used in the 1973 Supreme Court case that created a constitutional right to an abortion. In the adjacent booth a young man eavesdropped for awhile, then stood up slowly and approached her table.

LEAD: Speaker of the House Jim Wright, batting aside one allegation of impropriety after another, denied today that he had ever held up legislation in exchange for campaign contributions or taken a free ride on the plane owned by the operator of a chain of nursing homes.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that John J. Creedon, its president and chief executive, will retire on Sept. 1. Robert G. Schwartz will assume his positions and continue as chairman.

LEAD: American foundations gave more than $1.6 billion last year to colleges and universities, but the money was mainly for research, and academic leaders say the grants neglected the worsening decay of collegiate buildings and classrooms.
LEAD: Robert Thomases, an educator and former director of a camp for disturbed children, died Thursday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 71 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An agreement to transfer the world's largest collection of Indian artifacts from the Museum of the American Indian in New York City to the Smithsonian Institution was signed today by the secretary of the Smithsonian.

LEAD: Eleanor P. Brenner is beginning to believe she has succeeded on Seventh Avenue. Her styles are sold in 400 stores around the country. She has developed a faithful coterie of followers, including Joan Mondale, who write her fan letters, turn up at her fashion shows and buy her clothes.

LEAD: Two prospering regional banking companies, the Banc One Corporation and Barnett Banks Inc., are considering making offers for 20 banks formerly owned by Mcorp that are now controlled by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a Texas banking consultant said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said yesterday that operating profit for the company's first quarter rose 24 percent, to $52 million, or 25 cents a share. Revenues climbed 27 percent, to $232 million, from $182.6 million a year ago.
LEAD: Frederic Bernhardt Mueller, a former partner in the Pace Gallery, a prominent contemporary-art dealership in Manhattan, died on May 1 at his home in Oahu, Hawaii. He was 53 years old.

LEAD: Three business days after the California Supreme Court upheld the main provisions of an initiative requiring insurance companies to roll back rates 20 percent, at least 18 insurers have asked the California Insurance Department for exemptions on the ground that the change would impose hardship on them.

LEAD: The strike at Eastern Airlines has provided a textbook example of how adept the airline industry has become at using sophisticated computer programs to sell seats at the highest possible price without appearing to have raised prices and risking public ire.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Boston ruled yesterday that an effort by the Reagan Administration to prevent Federally financed family planning clinics from helping women to obtain abortions was unconstitutional.

LEAD: CASH flow has become the investment theme of the 1980's. For much of the decade, investors who focused on corporate cash flow, which was growing much more rapidly than reported earnings, were able to turn in a superior performance. Expectations of rising cash flows were a major reason that companies were willing to go deeply into debt to make acquisitions and leveraged buyouts.

LEAD: Eddie Johnson of the Phoenix Suns, who led all non-starters in the National Basketball Association in scoring with a 21.5 average, yesterday was named the winner of the league's Sixth Man Award. The 6-foot-9-inch Johnson received 33 votes from a nationwide news media panel. Thurl Bailey of Utah was second with 26 votes and Dennis Rodman of Detroit was third with 17.

LEAD: The Northrop Corporation has reprimanded its chairman, Thomas V. Jones, for the manner in which he led the company's efforts to sell the F-20 fighter jet to South Korea, the military contractor's proxy statement says.

LEAD: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, a long-shot candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, is the Mayor of Princeton, a college town that is the silky essence of the suburban dream. But she is basing her quest partly on a belief that the days of the suburban boom are over and that the coming era belongs to the cities.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: COULD another AIDS virus soon appear, this time spreading relatively easily in coughs and sneezes?

LEAD: Fighting to keep his place in eight lanes of bumper-to-bumper, side-by-side traffic, the taxi driver gripped the steering wheel and held forth on his dissatisfaction with the choice of presidential candidates in the May 14 elections.

LEAD: Aarnout A. Loudon, the chief executive of the big Dutch chemical company Akzo N.V., is seeking to broaden American investment in the company. So it was fitting that he was in New York yesterday as Akzo began selling its shares on the over-the counter market in the form of American depository receipts.
LEAD: Three people were arrested over the weekend in New York City on charges of heroin trafficking that officials said resulted from an unusual tip by law-enforcement authorities in China.

LEAD: The chief investigator in the Department of Housing and Urban Development offered a more detailed account today of what H.U.D. officials have described as widespread influence-peddling by prominent Republicans involved in a Federal housing subsidy program. LEAD: The criminal investigation of trading practices at four New York commodity exchanges is examining whether brokers and traders illegally shared information with each other about customer orders, allowing them to make trades before the orders changed market prices, people involved in the inquiry said yesterday.

LEAD: Top Exxon executives contradicted state and Federal officials today, insisting that they had repeatedly urged the prompt use of chemicals to disperse the nation's largest oil spill but the Federal authorities turned them down.

LEAD: Interco Inc. said it would sell its Central Hardware Company subsidiary for about $245 million to a group formed by Salomon Brothers Inc. and an affiliate of Handy Andy Home Improvements Centers Inc. LEAD: Marc Chagall's ''Violinist With the World Upside Down,'' from 1929, was sold last night for $4.6 million, a record at auction for the artist, in an auction held by Habsburg, Feldman, a Geneva-based auction house. The work was sold to the Fujii Gallery of Tokyo, Pablo Picasso's ''Dream,'' from 1932, which was bought for $6.3 million by an American collector who was not identified, was the highest price of the sale, held at the Regency Hotel in Manhattan.

LEAD: The proposed Staten Island jail and public campaign financing will probably cost City Council President Andrew J. Stein, a Democrat, the Republican nomination and virtual coronation for another four-year term.

LEAD: V. Hall Everson Jr., a former state representative from Greenwich, Conn., for 40 years, died, apparently of a heart attack, Saturday at the Hospital of St. Raphael in New Haven. He was 92 years old and lived in Branford.

LEAD: Joe, a prominent building contractor and apostle of the American Dream, worked his way up from scratch after returning from decorated service in Vietnam. He had to start out in garbage. In ''The Speed of Darkness,'' Steve Tesich's first new play since 1980, Joe (Bill Raymond) pays thanks for his success at the televised award ceremony naming him South Dakota's Man of the Year.

LEAD: For the second time in less than a week, angry Israelis roamed the streets on Sunday night and again this morning, shouting ''Death to Arabs!'' as they looked for Palestinians they could lynch, this time in retaliation for the death of a soldier whose body was found on Sunday with a bullet to the head.
LEAD: Cities and counties in the United States are increasing their spending faster than their income is rising, according to two new Census Bureau reports.
